title: ''Πολύ καλό''
text: Το ψηλότερο κτίριο στο Μπανγιούλ. Τα σκαλιά είναι πάνω από 100 αλλά μπορείτε να τα ανεβείτε εύκολα και χαλαρά.Μόλις φτάσετε έχει ένα χώρο με κάποιες φωτογραφίες.Και φυσικά έχετε μια θέα της πόλης από ψηλά.

title: Tribute Arch That Offers a Great View of the City
text: We appreciated the tasteful tribute to the military coup July 1994 that offers views of Banjul.  This is the tallest structure in The Gambia and worth a visit.

title: Nice little museum at the top with a really good guide
text: We went up there to activate our kids a bit - we expected a nice view, which was indeed nice, but were happily surprised to find a very nice and competent guide at the top too, in a little museum. He could talk for hours about Gambian history.

title: Dictator
text: De boog geeft een mooi uitzicht op de kleine hoofdstad Banjul. Maar het schokkende museum erboven liet een zwarte periode uit de geschiedenis van gambia zien. Een van de voorgaande presidenten Jammeh had het land geregeerd als een harde dictator met moordeskaders. Vreselijk om te zien

title: Panoramic View of Banjul
text:
Located on the Banjul-Serrekunda highway into Banjul, is the commemorative arch built in 1996 Provisional Ruling Council overthrew the democratically elected Gambian government of President Sir Dawda Jawara.  A statue of the "unknown soldier" is set near the base of the arch:
Construction

At about 90 feet, the arch is one of the tallest structures in The Gambia. The building has three floors. Access to the upper floors can be made through a series of several marble spiral stairs.  Although there is an elevator it was not working.

Each floor provides a panorama of the city, with the top floor providing a view extending to the sea port of Banjul and the mangrove forests of Tanbi Wetland Complex. In the third level is a series of photos of  President Jawara.  Worth a climb if you are in reasonably good shape.

title: im Verfall
text:
Die Aussicht oben ist interessant, aber dann war es auch bereits.
Der Zustand ist erschreckend schlecht und dann gibt es zwar noch ein paar Räume zum anschauen, aber ohne Licht, sehr ungepflegt und alles im Zerfall.
Kein Besuch wert, wenn nicht die Aussicht wäre; kurzer Stop und dann ist genug; schade dass man es nicht ein wenig pflegt

title: Site de la ville
text: Avec les mosquées, c'est le seul lieu qui semble intéressant à  visiter sur Banjul. Entrée à 100 dalasis pour les étrangers, quelques marches puis une belle vue et surtout le lieu de regroupement des habitants. De près du port le taxi nous y a emmené aller retour avec 10 minutes d'attente environ pour 200 dalasis.

title: Interesting history and nice view
text: Nice view overlooking the city. It houses a small museum and shows the history of The Gambia. Bring a flashlight because it can be rather dark inside.

title: commemortivo
text: Sulla strada tra Banjul e Serrekunda si incrocia questo arco che commemora il colpo di stato. Con la sua quarantina di metri è una delle strutture più alte in zona e salendo si può vedere il panorama. C’è anche una statua al milite ignoto.

title: One if the only historic monuments
text: This is one of the only historic monuments in the country, it's an important place to visit. Up high you get to really see the city.

title: Kaprys byłego prezydenta
text: Duża budowla wybudowana przez i dla byłego prezydenta Gambii. Dobre miejsce do podziwiania stolicy najmniejszego państwa Afryki. Widoki niesamowite. W Srodku muzeum gdzie możemy zapoznać się z historią Gambii.

title: Arch22
text: Vi besökte monumentet som en del av en guidad rundresa i Banjul. Trappan upp var trång men utsikten uppifrån var fin. Dwt fanns en hiss, men den var trasig. Kändes som om monumentet skulle behöva rustas upp lite...

title: No es gran cosa
text: Este monumento conmemorativo está a la entrada de Banjul, cerca de la casa del presidente. Los coches pasan por debajo y su visita es muy corta.

title: Niente di Speciale.
text: Leggendo le guide pensi che sia qualcosa di importante da vedere, però quando ci arrivi, ti accorgi che non è niente di speciale. C'è la possibilità di salire sopra, ma non è che si vede tutto questo panorama.

title: Triumfbåge vid infarten till huvudstaden Banjul i Gambia.
text: Denna Triumfbåge byggdes för att fira minnet av militärkuppen den 22 Juli 1994. Monumentet är 36 meter högt och innehåller dessutom ett museum. Vägbanan ut och in till staden Banjul som ligger på en ö, passerar under Arch 22.

title: Stadtübersicht
text:
Wenn man sich einen Überblick über die Stadt verschaffen möchte, hier ist eine Möglichkeit. Im oberen Stockwerk befindet sich eine Ausstellung zur Geschichte des Landes. Man kann aus den halbrunden Balkon sehr schön über die Stadt, Parlament, Hafen und einer Moschee sehen.
Das Gebäude ist in einem erbärmlichen Zustand, Fahrstuhl defekt, daher für Behinderte  nicht wirklich ansehenswert, man muss Treppensteigen.
Am Fuße des Triumphbogens befindet sich eine Tribüne, hier wird man schnell Mitbringsel (Bonbons, Stifte u.ä.) los.
Nur wegen dem Bogen hinfahren lohnt nicht, im Rahmen einer Stadtrundfahrt nimmt man es eben mit.....

title: Eher unspektakulär
text: Nicht wirklich einen Besuch wert. Es sich anzuschauen, wenn man vorbei fährt oder geht, reicht eigentlich.

title: Mit dem Markt zusammen anschauen.
text:
Nette Sache , man kann über den Markt und die Stadt schauen. 
10 Minuten reichen hier für.
Also wenn man zum Markt will , einfach mit einplanen.
Raus aus dem Hotelzimmer. 
Rein ins Taxi.

title: Ein altes baufälliges Monument...mehr nicht
text: Wir haben es zwar nicht bestiegen, aber man soll angeblich von oben einen guten Blick über die Stadt haben.

title: Historisch interessant
text: De Arch op zich is niet zo heel indrukwekkend, gewoon een panorama op Banjul. Maar de bovenste verdieping biedt wel wat interessants: de slavenhistorie. Beelden, foto's en geschriften moeten ons duidelijk maken dat dit nooit meer mag gebeuren. Erg indrukwekkend.

title: It is beautiful to visit the circle at wasu where you can spot different types of stone
text: I had a very wonderful experience.. visiting the stone circle wassu..it's also part of the history of the Gambia.the Stone respecting UNSCO..i believe it's also a holy place.in the in Gambia

title: Worth a Stop if You're in the Area
text:
I found the stone circles interesting. I had a good guide who shared a great amount of knowledge about the stones. It's a small area but it's impressively clean and the stones seem to be well maintained. My guide said that it was maintained by the community and they are eager to share stories of the stones. It was interesting to learn about the area's history but be aware that the guide will speak at length, so let him know if you have any time constraints.

Perhaps it was a miscommunication, but my guide said that he was a volunteer. I left a tip, but my driver said that they are paid. I'm not sure which was accurate.

I would recommend a stop if you're in the area. I was a bit on the fence about going, but I'm glad that I did. It was something different to see in this region of Africa.

title: Patrimonio de la humanidad
text:
Lugar imprescindible, ya que se trata de uno de los lugares patrimonio de la humanidad de SeneGambia. 
Las piedras de Wassu están casi a pie de carretera y tienen fácil acceso (también están indicadas). Lugar curioso, aunque le falta mucha información, ya sea con guías, carteles o folletos. 
Hay baños públicos.

userLocation.name: San Sebastian de los Reyes, Spain

title: Sehenswert
text: Unesco-Weltkulturerbe in Gambia, wie cool ist das denn. Die Steinkreise in Wassu sind schon sehenswert und beeindruckend und geben einen Einblick in die dortige Kultur wieder.

title: Stencirkler
text: Et par timers kørsel fra kysten ligger de kendte stencirkler i Wassu, i midten af cirklerne er der grave, som man kan læse om i det lille museum der er tilknyttet stedet! For nogle er det bare sten, men når jeg går ind i en af cirklerne, rejser hårene på mine arme sig. De er ikke noget at køre efter alene, men i forbindelse med en sejltur til Baboon Islands, er det et must at besøge dem

title: Stone circles in Wassu  ,
text: Stone circles in Wassu is where you the fine the stone age record to the Gambia  just like the stone Hench in the UK ,there is not much one by them, commonly they have been agreed to graveyards or burial grounds for giants or Promethean people, different location has different artifact about the stones

title: The Gambia's weird stone circles
text:
The stone man will tell you all about the stones. Except he won't, really. He'll get lost in numbers and theories  without really enlightening me on the origins of the stones. 

Which is fine. We don't know the truth about the origins of these amazing stones which makes the whole experience even more mystical.

If you're in the area, why would you not go?

title: Mooi
text: Op weg tijdens 2daagse trip naar Janjanburreh de stone circles bezocht .Stond op ons to do lijstje en blij dat we er geweest zijn.

title: Stone man is a bit lost
text: Stone circles in Wassu are Okay, there is a small explanation room with photos and text. The stone man who shows you around is a bit lost in theories about numbers... he hardly tells anything about the stone circles..

title: Highly recommended amazing energies
text:
My husband and I stopped here on our way to George Town we got to talk to the most knowledgeable man ever the stone man he really knows his stuff and explained everything to you and things start to add up once he starts to explain it all to you , as myself and my husband are into Spiritaul things we just couldn’t get enough of the place . We had a good stop here and also had a drink and lunch . We did notice a lot of the tours were just using it as a toilet stop and didn’t give the opportunity that we did with our tour guide, we saw some people that wanted to learn more but wasn’t allowed as it was a flyby for them, if this happened to myself and my husband I would of been so angry as you need to get to hear the history to understand the stones.
If you get the opportunity to visit this amazing place please take your time to talk to the stone man as his knowledge just wowed me. What I couldn’t get my head around was that all of the stones are in the sun but if you touch one it will be really hot and then another one will be cold .
It’s Gambia’s very own Stonehenge .

title: Wassu Stone Circles, Gambia  - Not to be missed
text:
We drove from Farafenni to Wassu (Farafenni is about 3 hours away from the Kombo/Serrukunda, including a crossing at Barra). The journey took us about 2 - 2.5 hours. We made the mistake of not leaving for Wassu at crack of dawn, so the heat in the car was unbearable (no air con).

Wassu is a UNESCO site with several ancient stone circles that, according to the guide, are older than our Stonehenge -  5,000 to 7,000 years old (the building of these circles happened over 1,500 years).

The circles are in fact burial  mounds for kings and high ranking chiefs and only one circle has been dug, in the 1960s. Due to local beliefs and respect the other circles have not been excavated.

There is a very good and informative small museum on site (see my photos), and we could even get a cold beer. In the middle of no-where, in a country where electricity is a luxury, that was a very special treat.

The entry fee is small however unclear (the ticket stipulates one number but the guide charges more - I think for their services). It does not matter, we are talking peanuts, up to 300 GMD for two people.

Stunning special place. The stones themselves are beautiful, and to think that they are over 5,000 years old is mind blowing.

I strongly recommend visiting Wassu, either by hiring a car or by organised tour from the Kombo. There are not many roads in the Gambia so it is very unlikely that one will get lost. It is 1,000% safe, the people are lovely and friendly.

It is not a big site but I needed more than an hour to cover the site, to see each circle and to take photos and videos to capture this beautiful site. However my husband, who was distracted terribly by the heat, would have been happy with a 30 minutes slot to cover the whole site.

The pile of small stones on the stones is a sign of respect from visitors.

Last note - even though this is a UNSECO site, unlike Stonehenge, visitors can access each corner of the site and touch the stones freely.

title: Mooie ervaring
text: Bijzonder om deze Stone Circles te bezoeken. De reden van de Circles, hoe en wat is nog steeds een onbekend fenomeen. Men gaat uit van begraafplaatsen. Moet je echt gezien hebben. Licht wel in de bush bush. Met een rondreis kom je er langs. Via Arch reisbureau hadden wij een tweedaagse naar GeorgeTown geboekt en bezochten zodoende deze plaats. Alles naar wens verlopen.

title: Beeindruckend!
text:
Im Zuge einer 2 Tages-Tour durch Gambia, waren wir auch an diesem Ort. Steinkreise haben ihre eigene Faszination, ein mystischer Ort!
Das kleine Museum ist nicht besonders aussagekräftig, lieber mit Reiseleiter!

title: Het zien van vogels ennatuur
text: Ik had een gids mee genaamd Tamba Jefang van Finfoot BIRDING, was een unieke ervaring. Mooi park, vele dieren gezien en zou nog graag eens terug bezoeken.

title: Nice for learning mire about the culture
text: This museum is nice for knowing a bit more about the Gambian culture, nature, animals, instruments. I got a tour around, which i liked. When i asked i was also shown the houses you can stay in. They were comfortable. Don't expect a fancy place like one of the hotels in the touristic areas, but you have everything you need, like flushing toilet, comfortable bed, shower, etc.

title: A little local museum
text: Worth visiting this little museum to find out about the culture and fauna of the area. It is a little faded but the information is all there and we learnt a great deal.

title: Dorfleben damals
text:
Ein kleines aber sehr interessantes Museum in privater Hand.
Man erfährt hier viel über Natur, Kultur und bekommt ein bisschen  Einblick, wie  das Alltagsleben in einem Afrikanischen Dorf so gewesen ist. Da es auch nicht weit von den Touristen Hotels weg ist, kann ich es nur jedem empfehlen. 
Schön wäre wenn es auch regelmäßig gelebte Kulturveranstaltungen gäbe wie traditionelle Feste mit Musik und Tanz und was sonst noch dazu gehört.

title: Tanji vissersdorp
text: Je kijkt met grote ogen hoe de mensen hier nog alles op een ambachtelijke wijze uitvoeren. De kleurrijke vissersboten worden uitgeladen op het strand. De vrouwen verwerken de vis : drogen of schoonmaken of roken. En terug zoals overal : The Gambian  smile van de lokale bevolking. Wij bezochten het dorp met begeleiding van "spooningman" die in één van de strandbars woonde. Door iemand mee te nemen, krijg je ook veel meer uitleg. De moeite waard !

title: Fascinating Insight to Gambian culture.
text:
This small museum gives a fascinating insight into the Gambian way of life and its traditions.

There are a few rooms dedicated to a particular theme, eg musical instruments especially different kinds of drums. A weaver making cloth the traditionally way.  A reconstructed tradional hutted Village.  Entertainment in a cafe/ resting area by two drummers.

Then went on to the fishing area by the shore.  Saw fish being smoked. Then the boats came in laden with fish.  It’s very busy with folk (mostly women, but guys with wheelbarrows) collecting the catch.  It got extremely crowded (but not as pungently awful as the smoking area).

An interesting experience.

title: Well worth a visit
text:
I wanted to learn more about traditional Gambian life, and this was the ideal place to go. There is a museum, a reconstructed traditional village, complete with tools, cooking utensils etc, a nature trail and demonstrations of traditional crafts and drumming.
Our guide was very knowledgeable and I came a way with a real insight into traditional Gambian village life.

title: Worth a Visit
text:
Did this a part of the South Gambia Tour.
Found it very interesting and the only place we visited that you did not get badgered.
Prices in the shop were genuine and good value.

title: Ein Besuch lohnt sich
text: Das Tanji Village Museum liegt an der Hauptstraße und ist einfach zu finden. Das Museum ist vielleicht nicht spektakulär, aber sehr nett gestaltet und gibt einen Einblick in das Leben und die Natur von Gambia. Die dort gefertigten Webarbeiten sind beeindruckend und eignen sich als schönes Souvenir. Ich finde, dass ein Besuch im Museum absolut zu empfehlen ist, wenn man sich in der Nähe aufhält.

title: Interesting glimpse into everyday lives of Gambians
text: I enjoyed both the little museum and the fishing village with its colourful boats and people. It can get very busy at the beach, but you will get a great glimpse into the everyday lives of Gambians and many Senegalese fishermen that come here.

title: A nice little museum - but if you've time take a tour instead!
text:
The museum offers a nice introduction to Gambian life but, having just returned from a 4-day trip along the River Gambia with tour company "Tour Gambia" (100% recommended), we felt we knew a lot of what was told us and/or had already seen many of the exhibits in a more natural setting - i.e. in a real village, or had seen the wildlife or birds along the river or mangrove backwaters.
So, if you have time and opportunity, I'd recommend a tour, even a day trip. You'll get a far greater, in-depth and more authentic experience, and a better understanding of this wonderful country.

title: A lovely little gem
text: We really enjoyed it here and spent longer than we expected.  The artifacts etc are quite dated but they are well put together and that adds to the charm of the place, and there were traditional African huts, and a wooden tree hut to explore.  We loved watching the weavers at work, one of whom spoke about being part of a family of weavers and handing down the tradition.  We also sat and listened to a Djembe drummer (they often have a full band apparently), and he was great fun.  A really good introduction to the Gambia.

title: Infos about Gambia
text: Very informative exhibition especially on culture, music instruments, history and fauna of The Gambia

title: Interesting little place, if rather run down.
text: There are two aspects to Tanji and most visitors will be there to see the boats arrive and unload and all the activity around the fish market area.  The museum has some local history and a mocked up settlement from the 1800's.  How accurate hard to say, the obligatory drum entertainment.  Worth an hour maybe.

title: A Very African Experience
text:
We visited Tanje on our way from Paradise Beach to Kotu. It is the home of the Gambian fishing fleet and an experience not to be missed. In late afternnonn the boats return. You can see fresh fish for sale including some large baracuda, fish being dried and fish being smoked. The place is a hive of activity and the smell reflects this!
We have never seen so many defunct refrigerators in which the fish are kept with ice.

title: Petit musée fort instructif
text: Petit mais joli musée, ce qui permet de se concentrer sur les pièces essentielles. Un Must pour les férus d'histoire.

title: Important to put this museum in perspective
text:
By today's European standards this little museum is a museum piece in itself. The displays in the natural history and agriculture sections are poor by any standards, consisting of poorly framed and fading photographs and a few skins.
The reconstructed settlement of the 19th century is much better and was made more interesting by the guide who accompanied me. 
However you would be hard put to spend more than an hour here. I was soon in the central bar/entertainment area where a drum band was playing (for me). All a bit uncomfortable and although I would like to have helped by spending some money there was no 'shop' or even any craft souvenirs available. A lack of funding is clearly a problem and such efforts to promote Gambian culture can only be commended and supported- just don't expect much. But in time things should change.

title: Very good and interesting museum
text:
This was one we were touch and go about visiting, but really glad we did. We took our guide from the hotel, which enhanced the visit.
It's a bit rural, but it is the Gambia!

title: Good example of a fishing village
text:
I really enjoyed this visit. We went around the smoke huts where the process was explained to us, we met the ladies who were gutting/descaling the fish and got to look at where they lived and worked in some detail. The smell was awful but made the visit. We then walked down onto the beach where the fishing boats where either pulling in or were already there and the queues of people waiting for the fish to be offloaded, there were families of all ages moving around.

A walk the the market area was also an eye opener, no ice for keeping the fish cold, just buy it a get it home seems to be the motto.

The Gambians are a generally happy people and we were made to feel welcome, the women and some men are not keen on having their pictures taken so just be aware of that, ask first if unsure.

All in all well worth a visit, I would have liked to have spent more time there or gone back but time didn't allow that.

title: Bokrijk van Gambia
text: Ervaar hoe de stammen vroeger leefden. Ervaren gids en op het einde krijg je nog een concertje op de cora.

title: Not the best
text: This market has lots of decent local craft items but the problem is some of the stall holders are so pushy it wears you down, even experienced travellers avoid it

title: Nothing Special
text: We went here because we were in the area. Nothing special. Just the usual stuff that is available on every street corner in The Gambia

title: WELCOME TO THE GAMBIA
text:
Very interesting to see Arts and crafts batik in senegambia craft market for the Best local Guide to show you around please kindly contact +220 7647423 

Thank you for your kindly attention! 
Welcome to the Gambia smiling coast of West Africa

title: Average dusty local outdoor market
text:
Typical African market where the same trinkets, crafts, textiles etc are being sold, mostly very dusty. Am the above can easily be found in any same place. 

Each stall sells everything the same as their neighbours. Even having multiple stalls. 

I certainly saw, like for like, in Tanzania and Zanzibar. 

DO not accept the first price. Offer a 1/3 and meet in the middle unless you're very generous and pay their inflated price 

All good fun and they certainly won't sell at a loss 

They're great vendors, chatty, friendly and interested in where  you're from.

title: Goede souvenirs, veel dwingend aangesproken
text: Een prima kleine markt voor echt Afrikaanse souveniers (tassen, sleutelhangers, beelden, schilderijen, sieraden). Ontzettend aandringen van verkopers, kon geen stap zetten zonder dwingend aangesproken te worden. Als tourist wordt dubbele prijs gevraagd, veel vanaf gepraat.

title: BELLE CREATIVITE
text:
Après la visite du parc , nous avons eu le plaisir d'arpenter le marché artisanal de Sénégambie, un lieu vibrant et coloré où les traditions locales s'expriment à travers une myriade d'objets artisanaux. Dès notre arrivée, nous avons été accueillis par un kaléidoscope de couleurs, avec des étals débordant d'objets en bois sculpté, des masques de cérémonie africaine aux motifs mystérieux, des tissus batik aux teintes chatoyantes, des vêtements traditionnels et des bijoux étincelants.
L'accueil des marchands était chaleureux mais pressant, avec chacun d'eux vantant la beauté et la qualité de leurs produits. Parmi les objets exposés, nous avons été particulièrement séduits par les magnifiques sculptures en bois, témoignant du talent et du savoir-faire des artisans locaux. Les masques de cérémonie africaine, chargés d'histoire et de symbolisme, ont également captivé notre imagination.
Les tissus batik, avec leurs motifs complexes et leurs couleurs vives, ont ajouté une touche de dynamisme au marché, tandis que les vêtements traditionnels ont offert un aperçu fascinant de la culture locale. Les bijoux, élaborés avec soin et ornés de perles et de pierres précieuses, ont étincelé sous le soleil ardent.
Parmi les trésors du marché, nous avons également découvert de magnifiques tableaux sur toile, véritables œuvres d'art qui reflètent la richesse culturelle et artistique de la région. Chaque tableau racontait une histoire, capturant l'essence et la beauté de la vie en Sénégambie.
Notre visite au marché artisanal de Sénégambie a été une expérience inoubliable, nous plongeant au cœur de la culture et de l'artisanat local. Entre les couleurs éclatantes, les objets magnifiquement travaillés et l'ambiance animée du marché, nous avons été transportés dans un monde de beauté et de créativité.
VOYAGEAVECNOUS.COM
FB ET INSTA AUTOURDUMONDE2023

title: Hard selling at its worst - avoid this place
text: I felt pressured into buying items that I did not need from stall holders. It was not a nice experience and it was not what I expected. I would not go there again, the prices are inflated and if you are not a haggler you get ripped off.

title: Beautyfull stuff (clothes, souveniers)
text:
There are beautyfull stuff at the market. People are very kind but sometimes its anoying they push you to buy stuff. Let people see for themselves. Pushing to buy is also pushing away. 
Because we left de market and did not buy anything. The 3rth visit i bought Some stuff. 
I bought 6 dresses and 2 Animal Crafts. Very beautyfull.

title: Not suitable for wheelchair users
text: One of us is a wheelchair user. The taxi controller knew that and he would also have known that the trip would be disastrous but still he let us go. The road surfaces are so poor that a wheelchair can’t negotiate them. As a result we saw nothing of the market. The taxi driver dropped us outside a shop having parked the taxi 200 yards away. We waited 30 minutes for him to pick us up because of the one way road system and the heavy traffic. Maybe others would enjoy the market but that was our experience.

title: Craftmarkets
text: Een van de vele craftmarkets. Klein maar prima voor een uurtje. Wel veel aandringen van de verkopers en weinig acceptatie van het woord nee.

title: Not hugely impressed
text:
Nothing special about this market ,better bargains can be found elsewhere ,
Some of the traders are rude especially the first wood carving stall on the left

title: Leuke markt met hele lieve verkopers
text: De onwijs super lieve mensen op de Craft Market verkopen veelal dezelfde spullen en voor dezelfde prijs; kleding, houtsnijwerk, armbandjes, sieraden, pinda's enz. Afdingen kan, maar besef wel dat iedere Dalasi voor hen heel veel waarde heeft. De arme, maar o zo vriendelijke mensen zijn zo dankbaar voor iedere Dalasi die ze verdienen.

title: Tough Shopping
text: 99% of the stalls sells the same wares. But if you have the patience to walk around and bear with the 'hassle' of the stall owners calling you....you will find something different...just like we did.

title: Honeymoon visit
text: Great little market full of woodworking pieces jewellery and trinkets you will be approached a lot just remember be polite and just say only looking but enjoy the African experience

title: Be prepared to have a lot of options
text: It’s beyond impressive that the people of Africa have kept traditional crafting so alive and well. Everything is one of a kind, and so authentic! MOST ITEMS ARE HAND MADE. From paintings, to carvings, to jewelry. You’re sure to fall in love. Also, everything is so well priced. Be sure to enter with some self-control, because it’s easy to want to buy every single thing you see!

title: Dont Go Alone
text:
Senegambia market is huge filled with people shoulder to shoulder selling everything from sunglasses to cement and anything inbetween.
The roads are packed with taxis ,stalls it looks totaly unorganised  but i am sure it.
If you get the chance go just to experience Gambian life but do take a guide

title: Mooie herinneringen aan Gambia
text:
Badou and Tapha jewelleries zijn erg vriendelijke mannen met mooie prettig geprijsde sieraden. 

Ze zitten rechtsachter in de hoek

title: sehenswert
text: alle Preise verhandeln, Verkäufer teilweise recht aufdringlich, angenehm schattiger Ort, liegt günstig in der Nähe von diversen Restaurants mitten in der Stadt

title: Good market
text: Much things to look at and much things to but. Remember that you need to discuss the Price and get it down at least 50%

title: Ferie
text: Meget spændende,meget anderledes end andre markeder vi har været på, det kan være svært at se ordentligt på noget da alle sælgere er meget anmasende, men samtidig er de også utrolige søde og smilende.

title: Fijn ambachtswerk en Afrikaanse kunst
text:
Dé plaatst om de krafters aan het werk te zien en ondergedompeld te worden in hun kunst. Stuk minder toeristisch dan o.m Senegambia kraftmarket. Onderhandelingen blijft de boodschap, maar probeer even door te dringen naar de achterkant (happy corner) minder opdringerheid en eerlijke prijzen. Een heerlijk ontvangst met de typische Gambian smile...
De moeite waard om souvenirs aan te kopen en te genieten van de Afrikaanse houtwerkkunst.
Jaar na jaar gaan we terug en worden steeds warm onthaald.
Een aanrader😍

title: Mercadillo para regatear objetos de madera tallados a mano
text:
Se trata de un gran mercado de artesanía donde encontrar de todo para traer de recuerdo de tu viaje a Gambia. Desde máscaras a tallas de madera de diversos animales (algunos tan sorprendentes como pingüinos y canguros) hasta instrumentos musicales, telas, camisetas y demás. 
Ten en cuenta que hay que regatear el precio pero sin pasarse ya que para ellos es mucho y quizás para ti la diferencias de unos cuantos euros no sea demasiado.

title: Traditionelles Kunsthandwerk
text: Wunderschönes Kustshandwerk handgemacht von einem jungen talentierten Künstler nameny Bayal. Hier gibt es Holz und Stein Statuen, selbstgeschnitzte tradizionelle Masken zu sehr günstigen Preisen. Der Künstler ist sehr selbstlos und verteilt auch gerne mal Geschenke wenn er seine Kunden sympatisch findet

title: Bargains to be had
text: Well worth a visit to see local carvers at work and displaying their item for sale if you see something you like always haggle and you will get it for somewhere half the asking price. It's amazing what the guys can produce and the quality is amazing!

title: Leuk deze echte ambachtslieden te ontmoeten.
text: Hier kun je nog de echte ambachtslieden ontmoeten. Licht toeristisch maar zeker niet overlopen, tijdens ons bezoek tenminste. Taxi Max bracht ons hier individueel.

title: New location, but worth a visit
text: I understand this is now a new location, just outside Brikama (rather than closer to the centre).  There are lots of traders and some lovely items, although obviously you have to be discerning.  When we were there there were not many others around so traders were desperate for a sale, and even us, as seasoned travellers and hard hagglers, probably overpayed for a couple of things (as it felt harsh to haggle too hard), but it was a nice easy to walk around atmosphere, with plenty on offer.

title: Good deals
text: We were probably the first there that morning so we got some really good deals. The first sale of the day can be really cheap. We went as part of a 6 in 1 trip so it fitted in well. This is where the bulk of the wood carvings sold in all the markets are made so they could be cheaper there.

title: Be prepared to haggle!
text: This Craft Market at the border of the Senegambia is one of many in Gambia and displays a wide variety of hand made local products. A must do at least once whilst in the Gambia. Be prepared to haggle!

title: Good market
text:
I actually went here several years ago but remember it well.
Good market for good variety of wood carvings. I even exchanged the T - Shirt I was wearing for a carving when I ran out of Dalasi to pay for it. If you like wood carvings this is recommended.

title: Great for craft souvenirs
text:
Visited as part of a 4 in 1-day tour with The Gambia Experience. 
Lots of artisans making wooden items with some great large items to buy if only you could get them on the plane home!
Other reviews suggest the prices are generally lower than the tourist traps such as in Senegambia. 
As with everywhere in the Gambia haggle! Personally I found that starting at a third of the initial price meant you ended up somewhere just over half the initial price suggested! Whatever you pay will however be a bargain!
If you have the time, cross the main road (carefully!) and visit the livestock market.

title: Leuk
text: Leuk om over deze markt de wandelen en alle houten beelden te zien. Maar na 2 uurtjes heb je al het hout wel gezien. Wij waren hier tijdens onze rondreis en alles bij elkaar was het allemaal erg leuk. Onze rondleider heette Solomon Tata wie kent hem?

title: Talented craft workers
text: I've visited Brikama craft market a couple of times now.  The shops each sell pretty similar things, although the style and finish may be a little different at each one.  The shop keepers are of course very keen on encouraging you to visit their shop and even though you've already seen the content in a previous one it's courteous to go in anyway.  The wooden carvings are fantastic and if you want to make a little change to something, they are very accommodating. For example, I didn't like the face on a model I picked up, so they chiselled it off for me there and then!

title: Onvoorstelbare hoeveelheid beelden, maskers e.d.
text:
Op deze handwerkmarkt kan je niet anders dan slagen voor het aanschaffen van een mooi houten masker, beeld of trommel.
Het vergt - uiteraard - wel wat onderhandelvaardigheid want alle aanbieders beginnen (vrij) hoog qua prijs, maar goed zelfs dan is het omgerekend naar de euro niet al te kostbaar.

title: Brikama Craft Market
text:
Quite small - but great value - depending on your haggling skills !!
Around halve the price of Senegambia and a nice day out.
Good selection of wood products all hand made - and they will make to order if you want - take a picture of the object - the Gambian imagination differs from ours !!

title: CRaft Market Brikama
text: Leuke markt veel te zien. Brikama is een aardig stadje om naar toe te zijn, een drukte van belang, wel gezellig.

title: Great souvenirs are worth the hassle
text:
This is my third visit to the craft market and I'm beginning to recognise and name some of the sellers now.  This is always greatly appreciated by the seller!
It is a little difficult to just browse here as all the sellers call out for you to visit their 'shop', however the atmosphere is friendly.  It can be hard to choose who to buy from as most of the 'shops' sell similar goods.  Try to haggle, I know it can be hard but it is actually good fun when you get into it for something that you really want to take home.  I'm never cut throat though.  If I would pay it at home then fair enough for me.
Enjoy chasing a bargain!

title: Estupendo mercado africano donde comprar de todo
text: Como muchos mercados africanos, el mercado de Brikama no tiene desperdicio ninguno. Se puede comprar todo tipo de comida, prendas de vestir, calzado, utensilios del hogar, herramientas... y como no, los famosos djembes. También se puede observar su construcción. Sus gentes son amabilisimas y buena gente. Eso si, un poco caótico, pero por eso tiene su aliciente de mercado africano.

title: Veemarkt
text: De veemarkt te Brikama is zeker de moeite waard. Tracht zeker in contact te komen met de plaatselijke handelaars... prachtige gesprekken!

title: Reise Souvenirs, Produkte aus Gambia
text:
Der Craft Market ist ein Markt der ausschließlich Souvenirs anbietet, dort gibt es ca 30-40 kleine Läden in denen auch hangeschnitzte Produkte aus Holz wie Pferd, Affe, Ketten, Teller, Schüsseln und sonstiges.

Der Craft Market befindet sich nicht am Brikama Markt ( Tagesmarkt für alle Produkte ) sondern am Ortsrand von Brikama Richtung Farato

meine Empfehlung: sehenswert es gibt sehr schöne Dinge dort zu kaufen.

Also hin.

title: Real Gambia
text:
The Real Gambia
That’s what we experienced in our tremendous three week stay in February-March 2009. We were based in Brikama – a medium-sized town about 20 kms inland from the Atlantic and an hour south of the capital Banjul. It’s a fascinating town with a vibrant feel but none of the tourist-area trappings and hassles.
People are very hospitable and very warm to strangers – especially those who are respectful and show a genuine interest in life there. 
Our host, Abdoulie Sarr, is a young entrepreneur whose aims are to create a range of locally-based enterprises to enable visitors to genuinely engage in the life of an area: get to know local people in depth; learn something of a local language; be part of local events; explore the beautiful country areas, learn about a different culture and exchange experiences; and to spend their money in ways that benefit local people rather than international tour operators.

Accommodation and Food (Vegetarians catered for)
He provided excellent quality accommodation and three substantial meals a day whist we were in Brikama. Breakfast consisting of a choice of very tasty rice porridge or omelette was delivered to our accommodation every morning and we had the option of having the other meals brought to us or of eating with his family. My travelling companion is vegetarian and we thought this could be a bit of a problem; nothing could be further from the truth. He was served excellent food with his ‘not even fish’ requirements fully respected and catered for.

Local Life 
Eating with the family was much more fun and gave us the opportunity spending time talking with people and playing with the children. In fact, we spent a lot of time just talking and debating a wide range of subjects and laughing a lot– a real exchange!
Brikama is a fascinating town to explore and Abdoulie’s relaxed but efficient style meant we could go it alone or have him take us to specific locations of interest.

Exploring The Gambia
We wanted to see the country and Abdoulie organised a three-day trip into the interior travelling by local transport and combining road and river journeys. We enjoyed travelling in the normal vehicles that Gambians used and not in luxury coaches or 4X4s – much more real.
Our trip took in the Wassu Stone Circles (evidence of ancient civilisation here); the wonderful Janjanbureh Camp with its perfect location on the River Gambia and good quality accommodation and food; the historic towns of Janjanbureh and Kuntaur, the bustling ‘crossroad’ town of Farafenni, the  riverside Tendaba camp and the rural villages along the country’s South road.

Birds and Animals
We saw hippos and crocodiles and a huge variety of bird-life along small backwaters that make the Gambia so attractive to bird-watchers
Abdoulie was an excellent guide with a wealth of local knowledge and contacts which made the trip run smoothly and tailored to what we wanted to see we never felt we were being herded along on a package tour.

Music
Back in Brikama we became familiar with the local music scene seeing a number of bands and talking with the musicians. Brikama is major centre for music using the Kora.

A Real Experience
The trip was a mind-altering experience into the way of life of a country with wonderful people and beautiful scenery in which the hospitality was outstanding and where we felt welcome and safe at all times. 
At the end we felt we had had a real experience and had got to know a place and some of its people in depth – a place that is now very special.

Contact details
Abdoulie Sarr provides a range of tailor-made options for accommodation, travel and local experiences across The Gambia and we highly recommend his professional yet personal approach.
Contact: Abdoulie Sarr Tel 00220-7722099/6720999; 
email Abdouliesarr@hotmail.com

title: Not worth it
text: Fairly unpleasant and glad to leave. Nothing special to see if you have been to similar markets and a hassle when “guides” won’t leave you alone.

title: Eye Opening!
text: This market is both organized and chaotic. I'm sure that doesn't make too much sense but that's how I can describe it. It's like your typical market- fruits, vegetables, general goods, clothing- you name it. It's broken up in sections so all like items are within the same area. It's not for the faint of heart so you've never experienced outdoor markets from anywhere in the developing world, I suggest a guide or proceed with caution. It's safe, no one will bother you. It can be overwhelming and you may get some talkative vendors here and there. I felt very comfortable walking around with someone who was familiar with the do's and don'ts of the market, so I was very happy to have a guide. I learned a lot about the market through him as well. He even treated me to fruits, and showed me some less traveled areas in the market that I surely would not have been able to easily do had I gone solo. If you're interested, his name is Kebba and he can be contacted via WhatsApp at +220 342 1046. I even contacted him on such short notice and he was able to arrange a tour for me within just a couple of hours! He's extremely professional, reasonably priced, excellent English speaking skills, and former Gambian military, so you're in very trusted hands.

title: ''Καλό''
text: Μεγάλη υπαίθρια αγορά που μπορείτε να ψωνίσετε τα πάντα σε σχέση με το σπίτι,φαγητό και για τους τουρίστες αν ενδιαφέρονται αναμνηστικά.Λατρεύουν το παζάρι στις τιμές!!

title: Great The Gambia Market For Everything
text:
We walked and shoppes through all the sections of this market that sells household goods, clothes, produce, fresh meats, spices, handicrafys and souvenirs. We could not resist fresh fruits, a souvenir shirt of The Gambia, and some good réplica of husos made into decor.  We spent time learning about various qualities, origins, and weaving componentes of colorgul fabrics.  
Vendors were generally pleasant with only a few marketing their goods with extra enthusiam. 
The market can be fun and can also have challenges.  Everyone speaks English. 
Delightful market

title: Gezelligheid kent geen tijd.
text: Gezellig/ lekker afdingen vergeet dit niet, dit is normaal / tijdstippen liefs in de ochtend i.v.m. warmte en drukte..

title: AMBIANCE ANIMEE
text:
Nous avons découvert Banjul, la capitale de la Gambie, située sur l'île Sainte-Marie. Nous avons exploré le marché Albert, un trésor urbain offrant une variété de produits et une ambiance animée. Ensuite, nous avons visité l'Arche 22, un arc de triomphe construit pour commémorer un coup d'État. Cette structure imposante offre une vue panoramique sur la ville et abrite un musée.
VOYAGEAVECNOUS.COM
FB ET INSTA AUTOURDUMONDE2023

title: Market visit Banjul
text: It’s a tourist market mainly . Very repetitive. But some nice hand made prices . You have to haggle but stuff is junk really. You cannot take photos of locals unless you buy from them. It is not safe to go alone as you get too much hassle and pick picketers . Our taxi driver accompanied us so no hassle at all. Didn’t buy  much but  nice to see locals selling their food. You can also see junta minutes island from there.

title: Bitter Kola
text: I like Gambians and the fact that they patronize us alot with our Nigerian BITTER KOLA. Love you guys

title: Smelly but good experience
text: Smelly and dusty but good experience. We visited this market with Buba tours. It was a nice experience to see the local stalls but be prepared for bad smell, mosquitos and people trying to attract your attention. We bought some wood crafts and cookies here. Visit this market with a good guide (like Buba tours) to find your way back out and to help you bargain at the prices.

title: Sollte man gesehen haben wenn man Banjul besucht.
text: Der Royal Albert Market ist sicher ein Besuch wert. Ich habe es mit einem Guide gemacht der mich angesprochen hat. Es war ein guter Griff denn ich durfte fast alles auch die Menschen fotografieren. Was sonst nicht möglich wäre und ist. Den fotografieren ist generell auf Märkte unerwünscht. Der Markt selbst ist überschaubar und man bekommt alles was man braucht oder nicht braucht inkl Souvenirs und Kunsthandwerk. Der Guide wollte dann für seine Dienste 800 dal was natürlich viel zu viel ist. Ich gab 200 dal und es war auch ok.

title: Nie ma rewelacji
text: Widzialem wiele rynkow w roznych częściach swiata. Ten pokazuje jak biedna jest Afryka ( choc Gambia z krajow afrykanskich ktore widzialem nie jest najgorsza).Masa chinskiej tandety .Zywnosc, owoce, mieso .Sprzedawane w warunkach takich jakie sa. Poprostu widac tu biede tego kraju.Owszem kupisz prawdziwe rekodziela ale to chyba jedyny plus tego rynku. Uwielbiam miejsca tego typu , ale to mnie przytloczylo. To jeszcze bardziej otwiera oczy na różnicę pomiedzy Europa i innymi czesciami swiata , a Afryka.

title: No point
text: Nothing to see except locals buying cheap Chinese rubbish and food. In a very crowded, hot and dirty environemnt. No lcal crafts or anything worth actually seeing. If you go in as a white person, you will be followed by some random Gambian people who will try and control where you go, engage in pointless conversation, ask for money etc. If you ignore them or don't engage, they will start shouting that you are racist and won't speak to black people. Avoid.

title: Good market
text: It's a good market for food, toiletries, fabric, fruits and crafts. I got some Sheabutter from the market

title: Besøg værd
text: Helt sikkert besøg værd. Man skal dog kunne klare den megen uro, lugt, manglende toiletter og desperate sælgere, som vil gøre hvad som helst for at få solgt.

title: Lokalt og fargerikt
text: Her tar du ikke med barna, til det er det litt for skittent og primitivt, men for en opplevelse! Fargerikt, lokalt marked der ting produseres på gammeldags vis. Jeg fikk raskt en "guide" på slep som skulle ha meg inn til den turistifiserte delen, men jeg overhørte ham så godt jeg kunne. Kjempespenende å rusle rundt i den lokale delen av markedet! Ikke noe å kjøpe for meg ihvertfall men interessant å se.

title: Johan oli markkinat
text:
Todella isot markkinat. Pienet, kapeat ja mutkittelevat kujat. Täynnä erilaisia tuoksuja ja hajuja sekaisin kalan, lihan ja kaikkien muiden hajut. Kujat ovat katettuja ja ahtaita. Todella paljon kaikkea myynnissä. Vaatteita, ruoka tarvikkeita ja paikallisia käsitöitä.
Kannattaa ottaa paikallinen opas niin ei eksy.

title: Not for the faint hearted
text:
We had a free trip and choose among others The Albert Market.
Its big,busy ,sticks of fish but not to be missed,its Gambia the tourists dont see ,you could get lost there ,every one seems to be selling fish,vegetables and spices,oh dont go to the tourist part to get ripped of .
if you get the chance go but take a quide

title: Niet fameus.
text: S’morgens hier bezoek gebracht. Markt zelf stelt niet veel voor. Veel kraampjes niet open. Weg er naartoe was wel leuk. Kijk ook even op het strand achter de markt.

title: Lugar asqueroso
text:
He estado en muchos mercados de África y como este ninguno: moscas hasta en la ropa... Olor a cloaca por todos lados, suciedad y basura hasta en los puestos de comida. Ratas en los puestos de carne y pescado. 
Terrible!

title: Toeristische markt, leuk rondje
text:
Leuk rondje over de markt. Hier naartoe geweest i.c.m. de serekunda market. Hele dag met de taxichauffeur. Is ook wel makkelijk, zodat je niet aan de weg hoeft te denken. Markt is erg toeristisch, maar je loopt er met je 'privé-gids' aardig relaxt rond. Probeer de koffie eens. Craft market is ook erg leuk, wel toeristische prijzen. Daardoor uiteindelijk niets meer gekocht, immers prijzen lagen hoger dan in 'thuisland'. Wel mooie producten, vooral van hout. Leuk om eens gezien te hebben.
Absoluut ver afdingen. 

Tip: combineer dit met een bezoek aan de serekunda market. Deze is minder of nauwelijks toeristisch. Waar de taxichauffeur bij de Albert market aangaf dat er niet zo heel snel werd gestolen, werd nu bij de eerste stap buiten de auto gezegd om de tas op je buik te doen. Al met al 't is relaxter om gewoon niets mee te nemen, want het is enorm druk en je stoot tegen alles en iedereen aan. Smalle doorgangen in achteraf straatjes. Koop hier een grote zak pinda's als je nog naar het monkey park wilt gaan!

title: Tagestour Barra
text: Ich habe das Fort und Teile von Barra (Black Cow Art Center, kath. Mission, Strandlagune) mit Mustapha von Tour-Gambia als Tagesausflug besucht. Schon die Anfahrt mit der Fähre von Banjul war ein Erlebnis. Ein Einblick in das "echte" Afrika. Alles gut organisiert. Das Fort ist sehenswerter als es auf den ersten Blick scheint. Ein Führer vor Ort erklärt die Details. Empfehlenswert +++

title: Incredible tour and history
text: I visited Barra on a whim, not particularly for the fort, but for the ferry ride there and back. I approached the fort, not really thinking much of it and thinking I would have a peak then turn around. However was amazingly welcomed by Ebrahim when I arrived. He gave an outstanding tour of the museum and fort. It was amazing to learn about the history and significance of the structure itself as well as the history, language and culture of the Gambian north bank. a spectacular experience - this should be so much more well known and on everyones Gambia bucket list. Easily accessible and hugely enlightening. If you are going, give Ebrahim a ring (you can find his number on the door of the fort if he is around) to make sure he gives you the full experience.

title: controllava la foce
text: Fort Bulle è stato costruito dagli inglesi nei primi anni dell’Ottocento per controllare la foce del fiume Gambia dopo che era stata abolita la tratta degli schiavi e impedire che altri la continuassero. Interessante esposizione.

title: Nice outing!
text: This place should be better known! The museum here is just as good as the main national one in Banjul, and because there are so few visitors, you get your own guided tour from the very knowledgeable curator who works there. There's some interesting history here, and the museum also displays some cultural artefacts from the nearby areas in the north bank. The views from the fortress are nice too. I am based in Fajara, and it was easy to catch a couple of bush taxis, get the ferry and the walk to the fort from the ferry terminal in Barra. The entrance fee is 100 dalasi.

title: Interesting to know, easy to reach
text: This historical very interesting fort is easy to reach for Individual Tourist and can be combines with a stroll Through Barra and along the Coast and several other places on the north shore. It is not very big but has an excellent Museum. The Museum guide Was particularly helpful and explained the history of the place in Detail. I Highly recommend this place for a half-day or day trip from Banjul.

title: An introduction to The Gambia and the slave trade
text:
A guided tour of the remains here is a good introduction to the positive role that Great Britain played in trying to end the slave trade. There are artefacts from the past when the fort was to help protect the entrance to the river Gambia and prevent boats collecting or taking slaves. 
Worth a short visit to the site and the museum but there is not much shelter on a hot day. The guide was informative and worth having.

title: A FORT TO FIGHT THE PLAGUE OF SLAVERY
text: After the United Kingdom abolished slavery in 1807, it took active steps to end it. Fort Bullen was part of that plan, built to counteract the slavery practices of other nations. The guide was excellent, visiting the entire complex. There is a very good museum on site. The cool breeze was welcome. The fort is part of the Kunte Kinteh and related sites that comprise a World Heritage Site.

title: A really Illuminating experience
text:
The Fort is both a historical monument itself and a working museum. Halima, the excellent tour guide, provided us with a fascinating insight into how the fort operated; its role in the abolition of slavery and the wider historical context.

I left with a much greater understanding of the significance of the river Gambia, the specific role of the UK, and the human cost. 

Just up the beach from Fort Bullen, a local educator is putting together a black cultural archive. The day we spent in Barra was a really interesting part of the trip.

title: Fort fra kolonitiden
text: Fort bullen er et spændende sted der fører en tilbage til tiden med slavehandel . Fortet var med til at stoppe skibe der var på vej efter slaver og dermed og et en vigtig del af slaveriets ophør . Et besøg værd .

title: Great visit
text:
Get a guide to take you over on the ferry from Banjul and then walk 10 mins. A well done museum  with ghoulish artifacts but a wonderful history of the terrible slave trade presented by a very enthusiastic curator who showed us around. Great views of the Gambia river mouth over to Banjul. On the way back look at the timber boat builders on the bank pieceing together huge planks of mahogany to make fishing boats. 
A lovely half day trip and the ferry alone is worth a visit.

title: A surprisingly good museum
text: The fort is easy to find, has a convenient parking and nice scenic views. It's fairly small, but it has a surprisingly good exposition and even better guides who gave us a very informative tour about the role of this site in the history of Gambia. Also, it's just nice to stand on the wall and enjoy fresh breeze, so even if you're not into history, you might still like it.

title: Worth a stop
text: The island itself isn't big, so it doesn't take long to visit. However, hearing the history definitely makes it an important and worthwhile visit. As another review said - I do wish they would keep up with it more if possible, as it's likely to be gone one day in the not-so-distant future due to decay (per our guide, even). Overall, definitely worth the stop and knowledge gained.

title: Kunta Kinteh Island
text: Although basically an interesting trip it was spoiled by the lack of investment in the sites visited, this is generally the case for most things in The Gambia. The government really ought to put some money into the more popular visitors sites, the Slavery museum and its exhibits were of poor quality and Kunta Kinteh Island could do with a complete makeover before it suffers from further decay.

title: Historie van Gambia, dit moet je wel gezien hebben.
text:
We bezochten dit met onze locale  chauffeur en gids Muhammed Camara (ook wel bekend Big Mo)
Op de afgesproken tijd was Mo bij ons hotel, we reden naar de ferry en Mo regelde  de kaartjes voor de ferry.
Ook heeft hij steeds koude drankjes voor je bij ( water- frisdrank)erg fijn gezien de temperaturen.

Aangekomen stond er een auto klaar met chauffeur en beozchten we eerst het dorpje 
historische dorpje Juffurey, beroemd om zijn connectie met de slavenhandel.
Hier had Mo een gids geregeld die ons alles kon vertellen tijdens het bezoek aan het museum.
Daarna Had Mo een bootje geregeld incl de gids om de oversteek te maken naar Kunta Kinthe Island.
Bizar als je erover nadenkt wat daar allemaal gevbeurd is, de mensen die opgeloten werden konden onmogelijk ontsnappen aangezien het midden in de Gambia rivier ligt.

Aan het einde van deze trip had Mo een lunch geregeld ter plekke, om vervolgens weer richting de ferry te gaan.
Interessante dagtrip, de meerwaarde van onze gids spreekt voor zich...alles perfect geregeld En hij kon weer mooie foto's van ons maken.
 Big Mo is een aanbeveling als je op zoek bent naar een betrouwbare, goed Engels sprekende gids, prettig in omgang is en alles perfect voor je regeld. +220-703 15 53

title: Worth a visit
text: Took the ferry at 6 am from Banjul to Barra.   Took a taxi from there for a 30 minute ride to a beautiful fishing village, and from there took a nice boat ride to Kunta Kinteh island, which is a very tiny island.    You will probably not hang around the island more than 15 minutes.  The area was beautiful.    I believe it's worth a visit.

title: Dit is te bizar voor woorden. Zeer intensief en confronterend.
text: De geschiedenis boeken in Nederland kunnen de open haard in. Tijdens deze excursie het ware verhaal gehoord van de tour guide en een lokale historicus. Neemt niet weg wat er aan slavenhandel en slavernij gebeurde een verschrikkelijke periode was. Om daar rond te lopen en aan te horen wat er allemaal gebeurd is geeft je kippenvel over het hele lichaam. Een emotionele zeer confronterende ervaring die je wel een andere blik geeft op de geschiedenis. Na dit kan ik rustig zeggen wat we deden was niet goed maar we zijn niet de hoofdschuldigen.

title: a deeply moving story
text: A beautiful place with a terribly sad history. The story heard from the natives, whose ancestors were part of it, reaches people differently. Traveling with Malcolm  from Gambia Favourite Tours is always interesting and well organized. The history of this place moved me deeply.

title: Kunta kinteh island
text:
Day trip to kunta kinte island. With a local tour guard.  We offer the best service eve 
With keba ecotours gambia u get the best experience u need to now

title: Thought provoking
text:
Don't go to see this island with a big tour operator in my opinion as you will lose out.
You need the layout and history explained virtually one to one as the island now is only a quarter of the size it was back in the days when it was occupied by slavers due to erosion and rising sea levels.                      
The island is a very disturbing piece of history and a place we all should visit a very poignant and thoughtful place.

title: An everyone is welcome
text: My name is lamin jammeh from the gambia 🇬🇲 I am a tourist drive in the gambia I went to everywhere in the gambia an Senegal 🇸🇳 i have been in this industry for 6 years now if u ar interested u can what'sapp me on +2203163654

title: Great day out
text: Lamin marong picked us up from hotel at 6.30am took us to a cafe for breakfast then across on the ferry, where he had a taxi waiting to take us to the boat to the island. After the interesting information about the cruelty of the British slave traders we toured the museum on the mainland and met some school children, then back to hotel. A very interesting, sad, happy day, thanks to our guide Lamin. £85pp

title: Worth visiting
text: A fascinating day trip around the island learning about the slave trade and past history.  Both of us enjoyed looking around although it was hot the day we visited

title: Informative and Authentic Experience
text:
My visit to Kunta Kinteh Island was excellent. I've visited a few slave trade sites in West Africa, but this one was different. I was the only tourist there and, although it was dilapidated, it felt very authentic. There are a few points of information throughout the island that provide some background and it's quite impactful to walk around the small island itself.

I would recommend a guide / driver as there are a few steps to the journey of getting there, especially from the Serrekunda area. Once we arrived, a local guide took the boat with us and escorted me around the island. He was very knowledgeable and answered all of my questions. I had read that the island is being impacted by climate change, and the local guide said that efforts are being made to restrict any impact. I hope that these efforts are a priority as this island should definitely be preserved. There is a museum on the mainland which is informative, but I believe that a fee is required to take photos.

I would recommend a visit to Kunte Kinteh Island to anyone visiting Gambia. I learned a lot there and really appreciated the knowledge from my guide and the museum.

title: kunta kinteh island
text: A UNESCO world heritage site. Come learn about the dark history of the West African slave trade and its history. Start off at the museum, and then take a boat ride to the island itself. Our guide Abdul was so insightful and knowledgeable.

title: Roots Tour with Armstrong Tours
text:
My friends and I booked the Roots day trip to Kunta Kinteh Island with Armstrong Tours, who were based opposite the New Wild Monkey Bar on Serrakunda in Kololi.

The trip was excellent, but what made it stand out from the trips that we booked through our hotel was Armstrong Tours, their lovely drivers and our guide for the day; Abdoulie.  The trip was cheaper, the group smaller (we didn't lose an hour picking up from various other hotels) and the transport was in a mix of pick-up trucks and jeeps, as well as the ferry to the North and the small boat to the island.  We had a much more authentic journey than that we would have experienced in an air-conditioned coach!  

The journey from Kololi to Kunta Kinteh is a long one, but well worth it to learn more about the appalling trade in human lives that was carried out.  Abdoulie sat in the back of the jeep with us en-route to the small museum and told us stories about life in Gambia, before passing over to another guide at the museum (I'm sorry, I've forgotten his name) who also took us over to Kunta Kinteh island, who was passionate about passing on the information about the trans-Atlantic slave trade, much of which originated from this point, and ensuring that what happened is never forgotten.  

On the return journey we stopped at a small village to distribute notebooks and pencils purchased on the way out. It seems like a minor thing but Abdoulie assured us that having grown up in that area he knows how important and appreciated these items are.  They stop at a different village each week so that everyone gets the chance to receive these books and pencils. 

Before boarding the ferry back to the South we returned to the local restaurant where we'd had breakfast and had a traditional Gambian dish of chicken yassa which was absolutely delicious.  

Any trip to the Gambia should include this historical Roots Tour, which most of the tour agencies carry out, but please think about supporting a local business before booking all your tours through your hotel or your travel agency, as not only are all the proceeds then going towards a small local business, but you will also receive a much more authentic, interesting, personal experience.

title: Be ready for an all day adventure
text:
The experience as a whole is definitely one that everyone should take time to partake in, but be warned that an entire day should be set aside for this adventure. Depending on where you start out, this trip can be very time-consuming, especially if you're on the southern bank and have to use the ferry to cross from Banjul to Barra. The ferry is inconsistent and isn't in the best of shape. 
Regardless the island itself is slowly deteriorating and the locals try their best to make it an enjoyable experience. The island itself can be seen in roughly ten minutes but I've found that the guide often makes the experience better depending on how much they actually know about the island's history. This is typically followed by a tour of a slave trade museum which is housed in an old British warehouse. The museum is informative but could use some better upkeep. Entry to it is free, but if you desire to take photos then you'll have to pay 100 Gambian Dalasi. 

Overall I think it's a great experience and adventure to have, but I think it's a one-and-done kind of trip.

title: À voir absolument !
text:
Le trajet en ferry est une expérience nouvelle pour nous.  Les touristes sont prioritaires pour embarquer et Bamba joue des coudes pour obtenir nos billets 👍🏿
C'est en pirogue que nous nous rendons sur l'île de Kunta Kinteh,  avons eu le plaisir de voir des dauphins 🐬 sur le trajet. 
Le guide nous relate l'histoire de l'esclavage en anglais (Bamba est là pour nous traduire en Français).
Vient ensuite la visite du musée (séquence émotion en ce qui me concerne 😪)
Et pour finir la rencontre avec la 8e génération de Kunta Kinteh. 
C'est la 4e fois que nous venons en Gambie,  nous avons fait un certain nombre de visites. 
Bamba est maintenant un ami,  il exerce ce métier avec passion depuis plusieurs années et est très professionnel, nous le recommandons sans hésiter. 
Vous pouvez le contacter sur whatsap au +2203643321
Vous le trouverez vers l'hôtel Ocean Bay à Cape Point.  Plusieurs touristes de l'hôtel ont fait appel à lui et ont été enchantés de ses prestations .

title: Eiland dat zeker de moeite waard is om met lokale gids te bezoeken!
text: Een superleuke daguitstap met onze lokale gids Willie (Whatsapp +220 780 7203) met onder meer een leerijk bezoek aan Kunta Kinteh Island en daarna het slavernij museum. Alles gebeurde op ons eigen tempo, we bezochten de plaatsen die wij wilden bezoeken en de luxe van privé reizen onder ons 3 was zeer aangenaam!

title: Gids Famara Marong
text: Wij hebben Famara ontmoet op de 2e dag dat we in Gambia waren. We zaten op het terras en toen kwam Famara naar ons toe met de vraag of hij zijn fotoboek van zijn trips mocht laten zien. Famara was erg enthousiast over zijn trips en kon hier veel over vertellen. Wij werden hierdoor ook enthousiast en besloten meerdere trips met Famara te doen. Allereerst zijn wij met Famara naar Galloya village, snake farm en paradise beach geweest. Famara heeft daarnaast ook veel foto's gemaakt, zodat we veel herinneringen hebben. Onderweg kon Famara ons al heel veel vertellen over de plekken waar we heen gingen, maar ook over de plekken waar wij langs kwamen. Daarnaast kan je Famara alles vragen, Famara heeft van bijna alles veel kennis en hierdoor leer je Gambia heel snel goed kennen. Ook was Famara geïnteresseerd in ons en in de Nederlandse cultuur, hierdoor hadden wij veel leuke gesprekken met hem. De 2e trip die wij gedaan hebben, was naar Monkey Park. Ook hier kon Famara weer veel vertellen en liet hij ons vooral zelf genieten van de rust. Hierna heeft Famara ons uitgenodigd in zijn eigen woning, dit was ook erg bijzonder om te zien. De laatste trip was naar Kunta Kinteh. Ook hier hebben we erg veel kunnen leren. Famara is niet alleen iemand met heel veel kennis van verschillende onderwerpen maar ook heeft hij veel humor en is het erg leuk om tours met hem te doen. Famara is een oprecht persoon die er alles aan zal doen om ervoor te zorgen dat zijn "gasten" de ervaring krijgen die ze graag willen. Je kunt altijd contact opnemen met Famara Marong via +220 744 1152, doe dit vooral als je echt wil genieten van je vakantie en alles wilt zien!

title: Long journey but quite interesting
text: This is an interesting and important place to visit on a trip to Gambia. However, a word of warning, the journey to get there is long (took us 10 hours there and back through there was a problem with the ferry so might be 8 on a good day). We went with a guide to make things easier, though you could figure it out yourself if you wanted. We were staying on the coast in the beach resorts (Kololi/Senegambia). First you drive to Banjul. Then get the ferry to Barra (not very regular, maybe 1 every 1.5 hours, takes about 30 minutes to cross). Then another taxi to the museum (this leg will be easier soon as they're halfway through tarmacing the road). Then a pirogue boat to the island where a guide (with not great English) will show you around for about 30/40 minutes. Then you visit the small museum about the slave trade, which is interesting but a bit basic, again 30/40 minutes. The guide charged us £80 for the day for 2 people (including lunch and water) and then we had to pay another £33 for the museum/island/pirogue. Then tips for all the guides and drivers. I expect we were overcharged and while it's a good place to visit, and the ferry and pirogue were also good experiences, I don't think it was worth it in terms of the cost and time travelling.

title: Sehenswert
text: Uns hat der Trip sehr gut gefallen. Erst fuhren wir von Albreda mit einem kleinem Boot nach Kunta Kinteh Island wo die Geschichte der Sklaverei erklärt wurde. Unser Guide Lamin hat alles toll erklärt, nicht zu viel nicht zu wenig! Wir hatten selbst auch noch genug Zeit um uns umzuschauen und Fotos zu machen. Dann ging es mit dem Boot wieder zurück und mit unserem gemieteten Auto eine Ortschaft weiter nach Juffureh wo Kunta Kinteh geboren wurde, hier steht ein kleines Museum. Die Tour war wirklich interessant und hat uns gut gefallen!

title: Zeker bezoeken, al is het maar om hen te steunen
text:
Afrika op zijn best, de “national Zoo of Gambia”, een paar hyena’s en bavianen, meer moet je niet verwachten maar dit is een unieke ervaring. Personeel is heel blij met ke komst en doet er alles aan om het naar je zij te maken. Wij waren de enige bezoekers en kregen een VIP behandeling.
Zeker eens langsgaan als je in de buurt bent!

title: Worth a visit
text: I think it was a nice walk, although it was at the end of the dry season, and at 37"C!!! We saw several vervet monkeys, the red colobus, a squirrel and an antelope, as well as several birds of all sizes. But the 1,5 litre water bottle was the best.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Zeer slechte ervaring
text: Geen goede ervaring. Deze uitstap zouden we zeker niet aanraden. Verwaarloosde dieren en verder niets te zien. Tijd en geldverlies.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Enttaeuschung
text:
Lieblos gestalteter Nationalpark in der Nähe von Banjuel. Die Rastplaetze wurden sicherlich seit Jahren nicht mehr angeschaut, beim Krokodil Teich funktiioniert das Fernglas nicht, die dortige Ausstellung ist eine Zumutung. 
Es waere ein Fortschritt wenn zumindest ein Mal am Tag der Abfall aufgeraeumt wuerde. 
Mitarbeiter gaebe es genug, auch zwei westliche Mitarbeiter. Aber die macten wohl lieber einen Sitzkreis und diskutieren als zu handeln wie wir gesehen haben.  
Es gibt aber zumindest etliche interessante Voegel und einige Affen zu bewundern.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Enjoy This Fun Friendly Farm Walk
text:
The cattle market proved an interesting experience in culture and animal knowledge. Our wise local guide pointed out three types of cattle, from Sénégal, Mali, and The Gambia. Soon we were able to distinguish the breeds.  He gave us info on likely trading prices and the keys to pricing cattle. We also strolled around sheep and goats, and had a great time taking pictures of animal antics. 
This is a great piece of a trip to The Gambia

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not great, pretty run down reserve
text: Not a great place to visit, there is a “museum” where they try and make you buy something to help with upkeep of the park. There aren’t too many animals there through the forest other than plenty of bugs. The zoo part had 4 sad looking hyenas, a cage full of baboons that looked they were going to break out at any minute and some slightly aggressive monkeys. Overall not great

title: Nature park
text: Beautiful peaceful place.  Some animals can be seen in their natural environment but you are not guaranteed to see everything as they are free to roam.  We had a guide that was very helpful and friendly and at a good price.  Staff were not pushy at all and were friendly.  Like everywhere in the Gambia you need to negotiate and know what's reasonable.  Be prepared to walk but enjoy it.

title: Vreselijke leefomstandigheden van de dieren
text: Ga niet naar dit park toe. De leefomstandigheden van de dieren zijn vreselijk. Meerdere hyena's in zeer kleine kooien. De apen moeten vechten om eten en zitten met 10 apen in een zeer klein verblijf. Al had ik dit van tevoren geweten had ik hier nooit naartoe gegaan.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing but exploitation
text:
If you are staying at a beach resort, the drive to this place is long, bumpy and polluted.
Once there the entrance fee isn’t much - but OF COURSE you need a guide. Then they’ll try to rent you binoculars.
Our guide was nice enough but basically it’s a long walk down a path through bushes. That’s pretty much it. If you love leaves, knock yourself out.
There’s a crocodile pool where you won’t see crocodiles.
There’s an ‘education centre’ where a man will ask for maintenance donations stood next to a couple of torn posters that haven’t been replaced in 30 years. And of course, next to all this non-learning, there is an ‘opportunity’ to buy stuff you don’t want.
Then more walking until finally you get to the world’s most depressing zoo - where they’ll tell you some thoroughly unconvincing nonsense about why these baboons needed to be in an enclosure rather than just free. Clearly just an excuse to get tourists there and to have them buy peanuts to feed them with. Felt really sorry for them.
And there’s the three pens with hyenas and vultures co-existing (emphasis on ‘existing’). 
Can’t see how anyone but the most ardent fauna and bird fan (not that we saw many of those either) could get anything out of this place. Avoid and do literally anything else.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Ruhe mitten in der Stadt
text:
Der Eintritt kostet 35 D. Einen Guide braucht man nicht. Ich fand den Park unspektakulär. Im Prinzip geht man durch einen Wald, kommt an einem See vorbei - Krokodile habe ich nicht gesehen - und am Ende erreicht man Käfige mit Affen und Hyänen. 
Pluspunkt ist, dass er mitten in der Stadt eine ruhige Oase ist.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

text: Nicht sehr groß, aber wirklich sehenswert! Vor allem abseits der Gehege beeindruckende Vogelwelt und - zu unserer Überraschung - sogar Krokodile und Buschböcke!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Un poco decepcionante
text: En lo que respecta a los animales, es un poco triste. Vimos un par de cocodrilos en el agua y unos cuantos monos (la mayoría en un recinto enjaulado). También había una zona con buitres y otro recinto cerrado con 3 hienas. Merece más la pena ir a ver monos al bosque de Bijilo, y los cocodrilos a Kachically.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Man sollte das  gesehen haben. Wenn dieses Stückchen Wald auch verbaut, dann ist es für immer verloren.
text: Es ist sehr interessant wenn man ein Nature Reserve inmitten eines Ballungsraum hat. Wenn man alleine durch wandert und ruhig ist (also ohne Guide) findet man spannende Tiere. Man braucht Zeit. Das Gehege ist für mich als Naturschützer eine Zumutung. Hab es mir gar nicht näher angesehen. Brauche sowas nicht. Die Affen verschwinden sofort wenn man näher kommt. Aber mit Zeit und Glück sieht man sie sehr nahe. Für Vögel war ich leider zu spät dran da müsste man früher so um 8 Uhr dort sein. 45 dal Eintritt. Fahrt mit Taxi je nach Verhandlung und Verkehr von Serekunda 300 - 400 je Strecke.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Dreadful place - just a way to con tourists. Avoid !
text:
Myself and my partner enjoy nature reserves and also sighting animals and so we believed that this would be the perfect place to visit.
We got a taxi there and the taxi driver would wait 2 hours. This was fine. It all went wrong after this! 
The park is 35D each which is fine but then they are white tourists coming and then the coming starts! Suddenly the price was 370D and forced into having a guide and paying for the taxi driver who wasn’t even joining us! Apparently it is too “dangerous” to go without a guide. Then after this rip off we had to hire binoculars for all the birds and wildlife we will be seeing. Another 100D! So far it has cost quite a lot more than expected. First impressions seem run down so I now wasn’t expecting much and was annoyed at being ripped off. What followed was a walk with a very sweaty guide with foul body odour who spoke not very good English. What I could make out was mostly about palm trees and the English man who originally founded the park just over 40 years ago. We were taken to the crocodile pool. No crocs to be seen. Disappointing. Two birds in the distance - use the expensive binoculars. Surprise, surprise they don’t work! We were then ushered into a dreadful “gift shop” selling over priced junk and almost forced to buy something. With a very poor booklet at 450D we just gave a 200D donation to get out of the room! 
After this it was a boiling hot walk through a sandy path with more nonsensical waffling from the smelly guide. We saw some monkeys in trees but this was it. The walk led (after what seemed like ages) to an abysmal excuse for a zoo. Hyenas in cages with vultures and baboons in another cage. Such cruel conditions. Some monkeys roamed around wanting to be fed which resulted in another attempt to take money from us. We refused. A man was trying to sell wooden ornaments. I didn’t even bother looking at them. Was so disappointed with this place. Luckily the guide didn’t demand a tip at the end otherwise the tip would have been - this place needs shutting down.

title: Stoffig.
text: Inderdaad wat vervallen reservaat. Stoffig pad door wat slordige!! natuur. Op het einde wat vervallen kooien met hyena en wat oude apen. Wel kun je hier iets drinken. Onderweg redelijk wat aapjes en gieren. Neem water mee en zet hoedje op.

maar vooral veel verschillen vogels en veel oude Afrikaanse zeldzame bomen..

title: Vervallen reservaat
text: Op dit moment is het zeker niet de moeite waard om het reservaat te bezoeken. Wanneer je pech hebt en niet met de taxi naar de gekooide dieren kan worden gebracht wacht je een saai zandpad van enkele kilometers. Daaraan gekomen zijn drie hyena’s, gieren en 4 bavianen te zien. Door de taxi chauffeur werd vertelt dat de overheid komend jaar ook giraffen en buffels wilde uitzetten. Hierdoor zal het “ Safari” gehalte zeker toenemen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Isla de Naturaleza primigenia en entorno humanizado
text: Mi opinión es desde la perspectiva de un ornitólogo que busca aves. Excelente localización para observar algunas de las aves más difíciles de ver en otros lugares como los turacos violáceo y persa (de Guinéa, verde). Se necesitará todo el día para recorrerlo. Hay que pagar una cierta cantidad (poca) de dinero y se tiene la opción de contratar un guía local en la entrada.

text: A beautiful park, the fact is that there are animals in cages but they are animals that were saved from illegal breeders.

title: Dit moet je echt een keer gezien hebben
text:
Het strand van Tanji wordt 2 keer per dag omgetoverd in een locale vissershaven. En wat voor één! 
Honderden, tot duizenden inwoners komen samen op een goede 200 m strand om een tiental primitieve vissersboten leeg te maken. Een drukte van jewelste. Kinderen en jongeren trekken de boten dichter naar de oever, en stappen met vaten en kommen in de zee naar de boten om de vis naar de oever te brengen. Daar zitten enkele tientallen dames op een hoopje om de vissen te trieeren,  te kuisen en klaar te maken voor de verkoop. Alles wat onverkoopbaar is, wordt gewoon op het strand gekieperd.
