Aber man bekommt auf dem Weg einen Einblick wie die Menschen hier leben und wie Arm das Land ist.
Der Park an sich ? Naja . Mit einem Führer der einem das Museum zeigt bekommen wir einen kleinen Einblick in die Geschichte Gambia s und man kann , wer es mag, Krokodile streicheln. 
Zeit 30 Minuten .
Kosten 1- 2 Euro.

title: veel krokodillen
text:
toen wij in gambia waren bracht onze gids ons onder andere naar de krokodillenpool, achteraf best wel eng eigenlijk je mag ze ook aaien. heel vreemd ook. 
maar leuk een keer meegemakt te hebben.

title: Pas terrible
text:
Il y a un petit musée à l'entrée, Parc très petit, nous sommes ressortie déçue...
Nous pensions voir une dizaine, ou même peut-être des dizaines de crocodiles mais au final nous en avons vu 3... Peut être que nous sommes mal tombée mais voilà on a pas vu l'intérêt d'y aller du coup... On paie l'entrée, on voit 3 crocodiles puis on nous demande de l'argent pour qu'ils puissent acheter de la nourriture pour les crocodiles... Je ne conseille pas

title: Great Expierience
text:
Me and my girlfriend went it was an amazing experience 
You get very close to the crocodiles and can even touch them 
Definitely a must when in Gambia

title: Ganz nett und lohnenswert
text: In der Anlage befindet sich ein kleines Museum, wo einige Masken ausgestellt und die Geschichte Gambias kurz angesprochen wird.Es war ganz nett, dort die Reptilien aus naher Distanz zu sehen und zu streicheln.Zu diesem Ausflug sollte man aber keinesfalls vergessen Mückenspray mitzunehmen.Für 100 Dalasi ca.2,-absolut lohnenswert.

title: Esperienza piacevole.
text: Certo, passeggiare tra i coccodrilli non è una cosa molto comune però è stato bello vedere questi animali da vicino. Il parco è un po' troppo piccoli per ospitare tutti quegli animali, alcuni dei quali sono davvero grandi!

title: Leerzaam en leuk
text:
Als je binnenkomt betaal je en kan je in het museum gaan. Daar zie je veel over de Gambiaanse cultuur. Levenswijze, hekserij, muziek, presidenten etc. Heel erg leerzaam dus. 

Zodra je buiten komt zie je al meteen krokodillen die vrij en los rondlopen en liggen. Voor een paar euro heb je een persoonlijke gids die jou alles over de plaats kan vertellen. Over de witte krokodil en over onvruchtbare vrouwen. Aan het eind van de rondleiding kan je een donatie geven. Dit geld gebruiken ze om de krokodillen mee te voeren. Als je echt iets wilt betekenen koop dan eerst vis op de markt en neem dit dan mee.

title: Crocodile is gevangenschap, toch voel je je er vrij!
text: Crocodile pool, niet bijzonder maar wel leuk om even te gaan kijken! Ook het ritje er naar toe is al een beleving :)

title: Familienurlaub
text: Dieses mal nur Frau und ich. Die Angst würde uns wohl genommen, aber die Tiere werden sicher sehr gut gefüttert.

title: Annorlunda upplevelse
text:
Vägen till parken är i sig en upplevelse. En äkta gambiansk by med vattenbrunn på torget, korrigerade plåtskjul och oblyga barn som vill hålla handen. 

I parken är det krokodilerna som avgör var du kan gå. De är helt fria inne i parken och du får anpassa dig efter var de är. Vi fick veta att de blir matade varje morgon så att de inte är hungriga när turisterna kommer... så därför är de helt ofarliga.... ;-) 

Parken är rätt liten men ändå väl värd ett besök.

title: Aussergewöhnliches Erlebnis
text:
Nach über 20 Jahren war ich wieder hier, um es war erneut eine tolle Erfahrung. Neben den Krokodilen, die sich wirklich anfassen lassen, gibt es auch ein kleines Museum am Eingang, welches die Geschichte und Kultur Gambias kurz behandelt.
Man sollte sich ein grünes Taxi besorgen, um den Ort ziemlich ungestört besuchen zu können, und vielleicht von dort aus noch zum Bakau Fischmarkt zu fahren.

title: Crocodile park
text: This place you have to visit, if you go to Gambia. Crocodiles are free inside this park and you go there to they area. You can touch one of the crocodile, call Charlie and that was quite schary, but it was safety. There is "nanny"  with you and they told, that they give 250 kg fish every day to crocodiles, so they are calm. Must visit place.

title: Bijzonder....................
text: Een bijzondere ontmoeting met deze reptielen zonder enige bescherming...……. Geen hekken, muurtjes of wat dan ook en dan laat men je ook nog eens deze reptielen "aaien"...…. Tsja, je moet er wel van houden!

title: Sehr beeindruckend
text: Wir waren mit einer großen Gruppe in dem Park. Die Krokodile zu streicheln war eine schöne Erfahrung. Wie schon beschrieben, werden die Krokodile mit Fisch gefüttert.

title: Sure, why not. Pet a croc.
text: It is an interesting place,no doubt. I ve seen and held crocodiles before so maybe I was bit more immune to the excitement other people experienced. Still, it was a good way to spend some time and the opportunity to touch them and pet them is great. You can get some nice pics. I still keep wondering why were they so lazy, even to eat a fish, barely moving,almost all of them. I ve been assured they are not sedated, just overfed... .

title: Beeindruckend mit beklemmenden Gefühl
text: Es ist schon mutig zwischen mehreren über 2 m langen Krokodilen zu stehen. Sie anzufassen (wer es sich traut) einzigartig. Eine kleine Spende gibt man da gerne. Der Führer erklärt alles und führt durch die Anlage. Schön fanden wir die Ursprünglichkeit und das der Kommerz noch nicht Einzug gehalten hat. Wir sind auf eigene Faust mit dem Taxi hingefahren und waren zu 4 die einzigen Gäste am Nachmittag.

title: Nothing to see, apart from some caged Hyenas and Baboons - hassle from sellers
text: Went here on a trip out, expecting to see hundreds of varieties of birds. Saw less than 10. Paid the entrance fee, was then followed by a manager who asked for a donation for food - anything from 200 to 400D, I do not know what they spend the money on as there seems to be nothing here that they need to feed, apart from a few rescue animals (and only a few!). After a walk around, there is a visitors centre - where on entering you feel instantly pressured into buying a t-shirt or other souvenirs. About half way around there is a shop, and some people selling wood carvings. You cannot sit and have a drink here without being hassled into buying a wood carving. If you buy from one seller you then get hassled by the other seller to buy from them too as they need to money to buy food!. On exiting there are a number of wood carving stalls that you have to pass. The sellers come at you from all over - one dragged me to his stall by my arm and told me that he had not had any breakfast and asked if I would buy a simple darning for 'only 300D' so he could buy breakfast. DO NOT BUY FROM ONE OF THESE PRESSURE SELLERS OR THEY WILL ALL COME AFTER YOU FOR A SALE. On leaving the reserve, there are another two locals who will try and sell you chilled drinks for an upmarket price of D75 (they were only D20 in my hotel). Was a terrible day out, it would be a bit better if they cleared all the wood carving sellers away - or only let one or two sell - not around 10 that you have to pass on your way out, all selling the same things.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Do Not Go
text: Went here on a recent trip to gambia. Don't bother, not much to see but trees and the animals are kept in horrendous conditions, so who knows where the donations go.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abuko
text: Mooie wandeling door het bos, met een vijver waar krokodillen zitten en een aapjes opvang! Er zaten ook twee hyena's.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Amper 'wilde' dieren gespot
text: Wij vonden dit park eigenlijk wat tegenvallen. De enige 'vrije' dieren die wij hebben gezien, waren dezelfde aapjes die je in Monkey Park (Bilijo Park) kan zien, dus als je moet kiezen, ga dan voor Monkey Park (er zitten er 10x meer)! De andere dieren (Bavianen, hyena's, een zelfdzame gier, schildpadden) zaten in veel te kleine kooien, en daarvoor kan je bij ons ook in de Zoo terecht. Ingang: 30 dalasi (=0,60EUR). Bijkomend minpunt: aan de ingang liep een man die vroeg voor donaties voor het park, maar zelfs onze lokale gids heeft ons dit afgeraden omdat je niet weet waar je geld terecht komt...

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great Reserve, Wally Faal, Great Guide
text:
I arranged this with expert bird guide Wally Faal (wallyfaal@yahoo.com).

We had quite the adventure and Wally really knows the Reserve and his birds.

When we went, Wally did not have his own vehicle, but he adjusted his rate and we all took a taxi.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Niestety nudny park
text: Ten park niestety trochę nudny mało małp i zwierząt polecam zdecydowanie park Bijilo. W Bijilo więcej zwierząt i duża frajda z małpami

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Wonderful
text: Hotel needs a little tlc , but look pass that and u would have a wonderful holiday , staff were so friendly and we had a laugh with lot of them , and went out with one of the staff for the day , good ok , pool kept nice and clean by ( chicken legs ha ha ) he was a great laugh, pa for fishing trip (great day out ) and well pa in side bar he crazy and so much fun ,ok to go to town the boy do wait out side hotel but you can just say no thank you , we didn't and they carry yr shopping and tell u about the town ( all they ask is a English pound , that's cheap to learn a lot . Great hoilday all round . Food ok .

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Prachtig natuurgebied
text: Zorg dat je hier vroeg in de morgen bent. Dan is het nog rustig, zijn de dieren actiever en heb je minder last van muskieten. Neem een gids mee. Deze vertelt over de planten en dieren in het park en kan ook heel goed vogels spotten. Een verrekijker is ook een goed idee. Wij waren hier later op de dag. Dan zul je geen krokodillen zien en je moet smeren voor de muskieten. Mooie wandeling door het bos met veel vogels en apen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Después de visitar el zoo...refréscate con Jungle Man
text:
El African zoo es una más de las experiencias que se pueden vivir en Gambia. Te parecerá estar en la selva y podrás dar cacahuetes a los monos! Hay Yenas, pájaros, buitres...
Justo delante del African zoo está Jungle Man, te ofrecerá refrescos bien fríos, y podrás disfrutar de un buen rato charlando con él, y disfrutando del exótico lugar tomando un refresco. Le encanta poner las banderitas que le traen los clientes y te dará una agradable conversación.
Ojo si es época de lluvias! Ponte antimosquito porque te parecerá estar en la selva!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Take a guide for a small fee
text: Nice walks in the forests with plenty of wildlife. We had a guide to take us around which was great. Very informative. I have visited here twice and enjoyed both visits.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Worth a visit - make sure you get a good guide.
text:
We had a mixed visit, in that there were no animals around (apart from one or two monkeys and some beautiful birds). However, we got lucky with our guide (sorry I can't remember his name) who was really informative and very knowledgable. He was able to talk passionately for the whole walk, which took a couple of hours. 

The animal orphanage is interesting, and you're guaranteed to see baboons, hyenas and lots and lots of vultures there - even if they are behind wire fences. 

Try to go if you're in the area - if only to support the business and the cause. Apparently early morning is the best time to see the animals.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Zoals Gambia ooit geweest is
text:
Leuk park om een rondje te lopen als onderdeel van een excursie, neem wel een goede gids mee die je attent kan maken op de dieren en andere raadzalen die hiermee vinden zijn.
De dieren zitten in hun natuurlijke omgeving (behalve uiteraard de dieren die in de kooien zitten) en het park doet enken aan het Gambia zoals het ooit geweest moet zijn voor het leeggeschoten is.
Je kan hiermdiverse apensoorten en vogels zien.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Outstanding
text: We had a knowledgable and attentive guide for the day who found and identified scores of birds for us. The Brewer viewing hide was fantastic and the whole experience perfect.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: klein maar tof
text: Vogelreservaat bezocht rond de middag. Niet veel vogels gezien :-), maar wel prettig reservaat, waar middenin enkele kooien staan opgesteld met apen, hyena's, schildpadden en pelikanen

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Interesting but very quiet
text:
We went on a day excursion from a cruise ship in Banjul.
The demo of palm tree climbing, juice tapping and the walk through the forest was interesting, but only worth doing on the basis of "we aren't likely to be coming to this part of The Gambia again". The constant demand for tips can be very wearing, though.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Hardly worth a visit
text: I made one of my Gambian friends take me here last year. There was little to see in return for a long walk in the heat. The guide insisted that we needed him, but gave hardly any information and neither the entry fee nor the guide's fee were cheap.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: The Animal Orphanage needs some financial help
text: Second visit to this lovely natural place, great for birds and walking as mentioned previously - however the small animal orphanage as it is called within this place needs financial help from what I can see.  There are some Hyena's in a large cage however hidden next to the pelican is another cage with some very poorly looking Hyenas with sores etc, I'm not judging but from what I understand, this place needs some help to make sure the animals are cared for more, ie more food, medical help for animals and better quality of surroundings that they live in day after day.  The baboons could do with ropes and tyres hanging and things to amuse them and play with for example.  As its mainly tourists that visit this place, they could increase the entrance fee which could help. I have may ideas as to how this could be improved and would love to be able to help in someway.  That said, the wild monkeys are used to people and they will come and see you especially if you buy monkey nuts and will gently take them out of you hand which is a fantastic experience and one of the main reasons i viisit the place.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great if you like wildlife & walking
text: Great chance to see some of The Gambia's wildlife but be prepared for 2hrs of walking in a wood/forest  If you go without a guide there are guides hanging around the entrance and they vary from very good to rubbish Unless you know the birds it can be difficult to chose a competent one.  I've had "guides" describe birds as little brown jobs and others that not only correctly identify but give you Latin names as well now that's just showing off!  Ask for a try before you buy  agree a price and get them to walk with you for 10 mins  and let them show you the birds you'll soon know what you've got  You can go it alone as it is difficult to get lost just follow the path but the good guide will show you so much more than you'll see going it alone and are well worth the 400D fee for their services

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Rustig park, pinda's voeren aan apen.
text:
We went here after visiting the Serrekunda market and then you notice how peaceful it is
If you are there for birds you can get a guide with binoculairs. If you are not don't think they are freebies and say no.
After paying the fee and entering the park another man comes up with a donation form for maintenance on the park. They should include that in the ticket price and don't hassle on every opportunity.

We spotted some beautiful trees and we came across some monkeys. (we dont have the expert eye for birds so we didnt notice them) Also some termite hills.
Somewhere halfway there were some animals caged up. Baboons, 2 pelicans, a turtle and some hyena's.
The smaller monkeys run around and you can buy a bag of peanuts there to feed them. (about 25D for a bag) The bigger ones come pick them out of your hand and they can be quite greedy so you have to throw some around for the smaller ones to also enjoy some.

More walking ahead you come through a souvenir area.

This trip is for you if you like to walk a small hour and like to see some nature and animals.

Afterwards we also stopped at the nearby goat and sheep market.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Still as interesting as it was 40 years ago!
text: I lived in The Gambia in the 1970s, and spent every Sunday morning walking around the nature reserve, mainly birdwatching.  It is such a pleasure to return so many years later and find it almost unchanged, though sadly they need more funding to keep things going.  The highlight is watching the birds from the upstairs viewing area in the large building next to the lake, which also has crocodiles.  Take your binoculars and you will see so many different species!  Then the walk through the forest is fascinating, so many different trees, and with luck you will see plenty of monkeys, both the Callithrix and the Red Colobus monkeys.  They are easy to spot as they scamper through the trees, and trees with have fruit are often absolutely full of monkeys!  Unfortunately I didnt spot a monitor lizard on this visit, though there are many large lizards in the park, and snakes too, though the reptiles are much more active during the rainy season.  Halfway round the walk you reach the animal orphanage, which is a very sad sight with monkeys and baboons in enclosures, when they should be roaming wild.  Its all very dilapidated and makes you feel sorry for the animals.  At the end of the walk round there is a craft market, not very good I'm afraid, so it's better to hurry straight through!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Bara positiva upplevelser. Monkey park måste upplevas.
text: Gambia är ett fantastiskt land. Människorna är vänliga. Varmt och skönt. Vattnet och stränderna underbara.

title: SMALL CITY CENTER, FRIENDLY MARKET
text: WE TRAVELLED TO THE MARKET - TO ACTUALLY BUY AN ADAPTOR for my computer.  Whilst there we took the time to check out the market.  Alot of the artisans and tailors there are senegalese and the music yu hear blasted around you is also mainly Senegalese. Alot of second hand and chinese imports too (a growing scourge across our continent) and alot of colourful but  african outfits.  Despite the lack of tourists many items felt gearred to the tourist crowd. Not a very exciting market if you were to compare it to the kinds of fabric and tetxtile markets one sees in West Africa.

title: A must do
text: See,smell and hear how Gambians shop .A real experience This is a trip you could do on your own but a guide gives you so much information you would not otherwise know.

title: Busy Place
text: An interesting experience as you get to see how the locals trade and buy daily goods. It is however very food orientated so of limited interest to tourists. There are some craft stalls which sell local wood carvings and cloths - quality is good and we ended up buying a couple of articles to take home. The place is very crowded and could be a bit intimidating if you were on your own. We went with our taxi man plus a guy from the hotel so didn't experience any hassle from the bumsters. They also showed us around the town & port areas. Would recommend a short visit but take a minder.

title: Third World excitement.
text: This is an experience not to be missed. It's noisy and gives everyone a taste of the real Gambian experience. You'll only go once  cos' once is enough.

title: Lively Local Experience!
text:
A local guide is essential,but well worth the visit. A real taste of gambian atmosphere haggling for goods is a must aim for about half the asking price its fun and you'll get a great bargain. Everthing on offer clothes, shoes, trinkets, hand made arts and crafts goods wonderful array of local produce.
Will try to force you into deals or purchases but be firm and friendly if you dont want it say so!
Don't go on your own as the "bumsters" as they are known are relentless to tip or buy from them.

title: Textilier av högsta kvalitet
text: Överallt i Gambia finns marknader som säljer tyger med otroligt vackra afrikanska mönster, både batik och andra trycktraditioner. Men ingenstans är tygmarknaden så omfattande som den i Banjul, alltså den som också kallas Albert Market. En av Västafrikas största. Alla ni som älskar tyger måste åka hit! Här hittar ni allt. Det kan bli gardiner och annan inredning, men också unika kläder som kanske sys upp av lokala skräddare nära hotellet. Kom bara i håg att välja en skräddare som månar om kvalitet, och därför kanske tar lite mer betalt. Ändå är sådana kläder bäst att tvätta för hand. De är absolut inte sydda på ett sätt som garanterat klarar vår tvättmaskiner här hemma.

title: Visted to see local crafts
text: The friendliness of the people.  We went with a taxi driver who stopped any hassling by stall owners.

title: Een drukke gezellige kleurrijke markt met een geheel eigen cultuur
text: The Banjul market heb ik ervaren als een drukke gezellige kleurrijke markt met een geheel eigen cultuur. Met name de fruit en de kledingstalletjes. Het contact met de lokale bevolking aldaar was enorm plezierig. Geef wel bij een eventuele aankoop duidelijk aan wat je wilt. Al met al een leuke ervaring.

title: Get out of your hotel and see the people
text: this market is a must see, it's busy smelly and dirty, it's fantastic, it's great to see the local Gambians, rather than being stuck in your all inc hotel, bite the bullet get a taxi (very cheap) and go see the sights, we found it very safe.R

title: A must if you visit Gambia
text: Serrekunda market is huge so it a good idea to take a guide along to help you navigate, we spend a few hours at the Market experiencing the amazing sights sounds and smells never once did we feel threatened or had any hassle from the stall holders. Our guide Ba Ba I must say was marvellous and made sure we didn't get lost. Well worth a visit to see to have a real Gambian experience!

title: Good experience
text:
I probably chose one of the worst times to visit the market this year as it was rainy season, so the heat was pretty unbearable. Not the first time I have been to the market, and it surprises me every time I go. A very busy place, lots of items on offer from jewellery to cloth, watches to clothes and shoes. Please be cautious though it is very easy to get lost and with the heat dehydrated as well. The place is sprawling and if you don't take a trusted guide you will probably not enjoy it so much. It is quite an experience to visit such a busy place, but please be careful, the streets are a bit rough and you can lose yourself quite easily. I would advise not taking young children there as them getting lost could be a real problem. Take water and if you can find a trusted guide from one of the more well know hotels then take them also. You will find that once guided properly around you can enjoy some of the wonderful wares on offer, and also the prices, (if you haggle a bit then the prices can be really good). The atmosphere is pretty amazing, its just so busy and to be fair most people are friendly. Overall an experience that sometimes I enjoy, but when it is this hot not so much. 
Just remember: Take water
                          Take a guide
                          Don't take young children
                          Use your common sense when dealing with people

title: Moet je doen, en meer zelfs
text:
Banjul market, moet je zeker eens doen, maar nog beter is met een lokel de markten afschuimen, serecunda market, de market aan de haven daar heb je wel iemand van ter plaatse nodig om die te vinden en van de haven te voet naar toe te wandelen, zo passer je de schaapswerven als ik ze zo mag noemen maar daar zie je hoe ze ook hier vroeger de boten herstelden of en maakten.
Beetje mijn hart verloren daar in Gambia.

title: Local market
text:
You can find everything there. Food, clothes, spices, fabrics, fruit, chicken, presents, .....
do not forget to haggle.

title: My trip to The Gambia
text: A great place to visit if you enjoy a place that caters to the traditional family. There are wide range of food and items to get at the markets.

title: BOTHERED BY BANJUL MARKET'S MINDERS?!
text:
BANJUL, GAMBIA 18 MARCH 2014

This country was made well-known to the world thanks to Alex Haley and his book “Roots” which was made into a television series, and tells the story of a native of The Gambia who is captured as a slave and sent to Virginia in the USA and the trials and tribulations of his life.

Gambia which is only 4,360 square miles is the smallest country on the continent, and has a cooperative relationship with its neighbour Senegal, despite having separated from the federation of Senegambia in the early 1990's.  Its first historical accounts come from the Arab traders in the 9th and 10th centuries, it was then taken over by the Portuguese who subsequently sold the trade rights to the British, becoming a colony in 1899, before finally becoming independent in February 1965.

We didn’t dock until around 11.00 am, so had a leisurely breakfast and a good sail in up The Gambia river.  The shuttle bus service dropped us off in the city centre, at the Albert Market, where we went inside the market itself.   This was almost a repeat of the other markets we had seen, particularly in Takoradi, and had the same produce as in Ghana.  

We then decided to stroll around the surrounding streets and we very shortly gained a "minder", who started to point out various buildings, as I was photographing.  We had been warned by the ship that informal guides known as "bumsters" abound.  Initially we ignored him, but when it became too problematic, I told him to go away in Arabic, which not only surprised him, but also did the trick, and he melted away into the crowd.  We then picked up yet another, who purported to be from "the security" force (which he wasn’t); he had a badge round his neck to confirm it!  He also proved a pain, and we stopped at some genuine police in the streets to ask the location of the internet café for which we were looking.  Having made certain we were on the right track, we tried to ignore Mr. Minder No. 2 only to find the original guy several paces ahead.  So we then had two “minders” to ignore!

Off the main thoroughfare, the streets were rubbish-strewn and potholed.  Even though we were the only white people, we did not feel threatened because there were plenty of locals around.
 
We eventually came to the Internet cafe and ascertained it would be US$1 for an hour.  As the internet speed was really slow, and after checking there were no urgent emails, we left after 20 minutes, thereby fooling our two minders who may have been waiting outside when the hour had elapsed.  On arrival back at the ship there were many stall holders displaying their wares on the quayside and I was tempted and bought a scarf.

At 5.30pm in the evening the ship recorded the shade temperature as 99.7 F, - 38C!!  However several hours later for deck barbecue, many people repaired to the dining room because of the very cold wind across the open decks, and the residual dining room staff had to be augmented by pool deck staff.

title: A Typical African Market
text: You should know how to haggle and bargain to get the best deal. You can buy African crafts or clothes.

title: Druk, druk, druk....
text: De moeite om te bezoeken, maar pas op met foto's. Niet iedereen is graag gefotografeerd! Voor de rest is het hier een drukte van jewelste waar iedereen door elkaar loopt.

title: Banjul market
text:
Banjul market is a big traditionel Gambian market. You can find there all kind of traditionel products like dryd fish, fruits, vegetables and flavors. you can also find a small part of handicraftwork, leather, clothes, wooden mask, animals and figures.
It is a very busy market, many Gambians are comming everyday to this nice market.

title: Serrekunda market
text: Locals and ex pats have renamed this market affectionately smellykunda !!! It is an experience anyone visiting gambia must try, the array of shops and stalls is immense tip take a guide with you to help barter with the stall holders and to negotiate the market as it is large and sprawling. A must visit, throughly enjoyable.

title: Craft Market
text: this craft market is nice and pleasant to walk round but you do get stopped a lot with the stall holders so it takes longer to get round, all the stalls seem to be selling the same stuff

title: Nice crafts but pricey
text: Its a lovely place to visit but you have to be armed with your haggling skills if you intend buying when go here as things are abit pricey and sellers alway try to out-buck you for a higher deal

title: A busy place
text:
The craft market is purely for the tourists but the skills on show are long lost in the UK.
The woodcarving, tie and die fabrics, ceramics, stuff made from rubbish and turned into art... brilliant.

title: gambia at its best.
text: people are nice,very polite,we ate a lot outside of the hotel&the senegambia strip with the locals.if u ask a local what he /she wants to eat its always chicken.

title: OK if you like wood carvings and batik
text: You need to haggle or you wil pay over the odds. Not a lot to buy unless you like wood carvings ,batik and beaded jewellery.

title: meeting locals
text: very interesting visit although the smell at certain stalls can be sickly. one thing to be wary of is some of the locals do not like you taking photos or videos of them. they can get annoyed with you. something to do with taking the spirit out of their bodies.

title: Avoid at all costs
text: The bumsters are really out in force here. Every cubicle feels like a danger zone. You get hassled non stop and I felt very threatened and could not wait to get away.

title: kleine gezellige markt
text: De Senegambia Craft Market is een kleine maar gezellige markt in de buurt van het Senegambia hotel. Er worden vooral souvenirs voor toeristen aangeboden. Vaak spullen die niet in Gambia geproduceerd zijn.

title: Overpriced
text: Expect quite a lot of hassle; much more interesting and better value at Serrekunda market (which is probably the source of many of the goods on sale here!)

title: bargain hunting
text: a lovely market brilliant for carvings and afican jewellery etc lots of fun bartering offer then about a third of the price they quote please visit Gambia no ebola there they need tourism

title: Geweldige markt
text: zeg dat je rustig wil kijken, en alles wil zien en niet van opdringerige verkoop houdt, en alles komt goed

title: leuke markt , niet al te groot
text:
leuke dingen , maar rustig kijken valt niet mee .
als je ergens kijkt moet je gelijk in de shop komen want kijken kost niets , hahahaa ja dat weten we .

title: Mobbed
text: We cannot tell you too much as we didn't stay long enough! You were mobbed from all sides as soon as you enter and it can be intimidating. What we did see was very run ofthe mill tourist tat tha t you get in all holiday resorts. There is no such thing as browsing in this market, I wouldn't recommend going although with very little else to do in the so called resort I guess they have a captive market.

title: Plenty to see and do
text: Very busy, great to experience African life.  Haggle and hunt for some bargains!  You can buy anything here from fish, meat and vegetables to cocoa butter moisturiser to clothes dye!  We bought some pencils to give out to local children in the villages.

title: Typical market
text: Good market with plenty to browse around, be ready to barter and you will have a great experience all tastes catered for!

title: good local market
text: all locals go here,great market to get the local feel of gambia,we had local guide,explained everything,not much to buy,but great experience

title: Nothing bad, just all a bit the same as any other.
text: The stalls are all very much the same as you find else where, carvings, shells, jewellery, drums, cloths etc. Store holders, not too hasslesome like some others. Didn't buy anything as nothing that took my eye. The ladies selling fruit and nuts are nice and very friendly, would go there again to get supplies. Do drive a hard bargain though.

title: worth a visit
text: was fun bartering give it a go!!  lots of tourist items to buy cheaper than the hotels, so worth a visit

title: Crowdy but interesting
text: Definitely a place to have a look at for the brave. Be aware of the hassling. Be firm but polite and there is a lot of goodies to find.

title: great
text: a great place to pick up a bargin. Do not be put off by the haggling they do expect it. A good tip is to go in the evening about 7 before they close

title: Fantastic!
text: What a great place! Really enjoyed going around the museums, very interesting, but absolutely loved seeing the crocodiles, I got to stroke one, which is a first for me. Wonderful experience!

title: Très beau parc de petite taille
text: Très belle expérience, vous pourrez toucher les crocodiles, ils ne sont pas drogués certains avancent lentement et quand le garde donne un ordre , ils se couchent.Entrée 100 dalasis ( musée et crocodiles)

title: Lamgil trips
text:
Another leg  of our excellent trip with lamin (lamgil trips and excursions).

The guy who talks with s brilliant English accent talks with passion how he looks after the crocodiles.

A brilliant experience and please leave a tip as this is how he feeds the crocodiles.

Brilliant

title: Leuk om eens een krokodil te aaien
text:
Op zich is het niet veel zaaks, maar als je toch in de buurt bent, dan kan je maar beter eens van de gelegenheid gebruik maken om eens een krokodil te aaien.
Het kost niet veel geld om binnen te komen. Je krijgt een klein museum te zien, en nadien kan je dan een krokodil aaien, en je krijgt er wat uitleg bij.

title: Krokodile
text: Die Krokodile lassen sich streicheln, da sie von Geburt an nur mit Fisch gefüttert werden. Der Park ist nett angelegt, die Guides erklären alles gut und sind nett. Man muss sich allerdings bewusst sein das der Pool in einem der ärmsten Vierteln der Stadt liegt. Schon schwierig zu sehen wie man dort leben muss. Sind dort hin gelaufen, haben überall freundliche und hilfsbereite Menschen getroffen.

title: Excellent
text:
Until now the closest I had ever come to seeing the crocodile was through the television
I know you can see them in a zoo but it’s not the Same as seeing them for real this beats the Zoo experience

title: Spännande upplevelse
text: Med ett visst mått av skräckblandad förtjusning besökte vi stället. Vi tog mod till oss och klappade ett par av krokodilerna utan att bli av med en enda kroppsdel 😊

title: Old Crocs
text: Worth a visit but nothing to write home about, the small musemn before you go in is very interesting and tells how life was in the earlier days.

title: Krokodillen aaien
text:
De ‘Katchikally Heilige krokodillenvijver’ is mogelijk niet de meest spectaculaire activiteit in Bakau, maar bijzonder is het wel om tussen een 6-tal krokodillen door te lopen en er een of meer (over de rug) te wrijven of te aaien. Waar kun je dit elders? Wij bezochten Katchikally in het kader van de door “African Adventure Travel & Tours” georganiseerde, half daagse “Orientation Tour”. De boeking hebben we afgesloten bij de reisleiding van Corendon; prijs: € 30,- p.p. Feitelijk hoort dit bezoek ook bij de ‘Coleur locale’ van de kustplaats Bakau en is een bezoek daarom best aan te bevelen.
Je kunt dit ook op eigen gelegenheid doen; het is 20 minuten lopen vanaf hotel Sun Beach (Kofi Annan Street) naar deze pool. Misschien is het aanbevelenswaardig om je door een lokale gids (overal wel in de buurt van de hotels aan te treffen) te laten begeleiden want de laatste 500 meter gaat door een aantal – althans voor onze begrippen sloppen en steegjes – waar je je mogelijk niet helemaal op je gemak zult voelen.
Bijzonder groot is de vijver niet; in minder dan 10 minuten loop je er helemaal omheen. Een gids vertelt iets over de ontstaansgeschiedenis en het feit dat het water vruchtbaarheidsbevorderend zou werken. Dus wie wil douchen met dit water is bij deze uitgenodigd. Aan de ingang is een klein museum ingericht. Bij de rondleiding gaat er helaas door het gebrekkige Engels een deel van de informatie aan je voorbij.
Maar met een krokodil op de foto blijft toch altijd een aandenken…

title: Interessant en laagdrempelig
text: Als je je vakantie aan de westkust doorbrengt, is dit een leuke bezienswaardigheid als je nog een uurtje overhebt. Wij waren hier met onze vakantiegids Buba en hij weet enorm veel te vertellen over de krokodillen, maar ook zijn natuurlijke vijand die hier rondloopt! Het is niet heel groot, er staat nog een klein museum en een prachtige boom. Aan een uurtje heb je wel voldoende. Interessant om te bezoeken, niet duur.

title: Amazing
text:
What an amazing experience from when you arrive to see the interesting museum with local instruments and the history of The Gambia, then on to the crocodile pool. not quite knowing what to expect its surreal to see the crocodile roaming free and to be able to touch them. All this for 100 GD.
 bargain.

title: Spännande
text: Vi var där för fem år sedan förra gången. Nu återvände vi med ett barnbarn på 4,5 år. Väldigt annorlunda att upptäcka allt på nytt med ett barn. Absolut ska man dit och klappa krokodiler. Skillnaden denna gång var att det ”tiggdes” pengar till krokodilmat. Vår lokalguide avrådde oss.

title: Krokodile zum Anfassen
text: Wir sind als Gruppe vom BB Hotel mit dem Fahrrad hingefahren, vorbei an den Botschaften, Residenzen, aber auch durch die Sandwege des Ortes. Krassere Gegensätze kann man nicht sehen. Aber auch die arme Bevölkerung ist sehr, sehr freundlich. Eingangs des Parks zunächst das Museum zur Historie des Landes, dann der Weg durch den Park, vorbei am riesigen Silk Tree hin zum Krokodilteich. Von Guides werden ausreichende Erläuterungen gegeben und dann - wer mag- dürfen freilaufend Krokodile unter Aussicht gestreichelt werden. Lohnende Besuch, sehr zu empfehlen.

title: Crocodile pool
text: De gids kent alle krokodillen en verteld je de ins en outs! Bijzonder om krokodillen van zo dichtbij te kunnen zien en te kunnen aanraken! Ook het kleine museum is even de moeite waard om langs te gaan.

title: Crocodiles + museum = experience!
text:
Read somewhere that people had written that the museum on site wasnt according to the ”standard” they were used to. I think these people have the wrong expectations.

The museum and the park itself is small but it tells you a lots of stories about The Gambia; history, politics, people, the different tribes and their customs (clothes, instruments). I got a lot of insights during this visit, and I am thrilled to understand some of the differences and similarities between the different tribes.

Walking towards the crocodile pool we passed a -huge- tree with a hollow body that could encircle ten of us (photo session time), a lots of other trees and lianes (shadow!), and fields were the women work with the family crops (photo session time).

The crocodile pool was at first glance not that much to talk about, but suddenly they were crawling up to meet us and there were crocodiles everywhere. Cool and a bit scary :)

If you want to be close to a crocodile, go here. If you dont, stay home.
And, dont be stupid, they are still crocodiles even when they are recently fed ;)

title: Crocodille Charlie bezocht en een Krokodil geaaid.
text: Leuke krokodillen bad. leuk personeel. Leuk om 1 van zo dichtbij te zien en aan te kunnen raken zonder gevaar.

title: Tama Krokodiler....
text:
Ja det låter märkligt men det är verkligen tama dessa …. gjorde inte mig mindre rädd men man kan klappa den =) 
det är en liten pool... naturpool man kan gå runt med ca 200 krokodiler…. ligger i Bakau så det är ingen lång utflykt men kanske 1-2 timmar

title: Dont expect to much
text: We took a taxi from the hotel, about £3, and he waited for us.  At the end of a narrow track is the crocodile pool, a small fee of about £1 to enter.  There is a small museum which is interesting and crocodiles lying around a pool.  They are wandering around freely so dont stand too close.  There is a stall and a lady making tea.  A nice afternoon visit.

title: Pieni pettymys
text: Koko paikka oli pettymys. Pääsi kyllä koskettelemaan krokodiilin mutta. Paikka oli yksi pieni kuoppa missä eleli kuulemma monta sataa krokotiiliä, rahaa halusivat sisäänpääsyn lisäksi vielä sisällä krokotiilien ylläpitämiseen.

title: Nature at its finest
text: With a historical museum to walk through, educating us of Gambian soldiers who fought in the world war and local traditional practices, and much more was a nice informative way to start of a great trip. To see crocodiles up close in the flesh, at such peace is a true experience. Been twice now once with and once without children. Both very enjoyable experiences.

title: good market
text: Excellent market for material, and also for wood - best there is apart from Brikama... worth walking down on the beach towards the barra ferry as well - as this is an experience...

title: A walk down the lanes
text: We had our taxi driver as a guide for this trip. I think we would have got lost in all the little alleyways otherwise. He took us to lots of interesting stalls and it was fun battering with the stall holders who were all so friendly. Pity about the rubbish everywhere but this was typical of The Gambia. Put up with it and the place is so interesting. We saw school children, having finished school, learning the trade of making the colourful clothes worn in The Gambia and even smaller children carrying trays of water contained in small clear plastic bags which added to the rubbish. Noisy and cheerful. A great experience

title: Survive This and You Can Survive Anything
text:
Yep, that's how they advertise this incredible experience & how true that is... Bustling, vibvrant, colourful and simply out of this world. Welcome to The real Gambia my friend... Here at Banjul Market one can buy almost anything from a single colour nut to chew throughout the day to a hundredweight of sun-dried lady fish...Just watch where you put your feet. Surprisingly very little hassle, so don't worry. Keep moving and enjoy. We certainly did...

All Good Things, Neville & Jill Pettitt (England UK)

title: Great place to visit
text: What can I say we really enjoyed our trip here. Really busy market full of locals going about the their business. Well worth a trip to see how the smiling Gambians go about their stuff.

title: An experience!
text: We saw a bit of the real life of the people of Gambia as, with no fridges, market day is every day. Crowded and colourful with sights and smells we are not used to in our ultra hygienic world.

title: a sensory delight
text: Everybody should go to this market, it is a sensory delight. This is a must visit, as photos do not give you the different smells and sounds. Get a good guide and this experience you shall never forget.

title: Hectic, Crazy and fun
text: Don't mind everybody approaching you, that is a part of the experience. You see how the majority of the local Gambians make business and what they mainly sell. Always bargain.. 90% discount and you will achieve a fair price.

title: No hassle.
text: Quite an experience, loads to see and all sorts of things for sale, as usual if buying dont accept the first price, it is mainly for locals, but they are used to tourists. Perfectly safe, just use a little common sense re bags etc.

title: Just a market
text: Good idea to go with a Gambian so you will be left alone. Most things that a tourist would want to buy can be purchased from hotel shop or other street seller and you will get the same price all you have to do his haggle

title: Be careful of the pick pockets
text: Ok market, not so big as compared to the ones in Nigeria. However, good for sight seeing, buying also and having a feel of The Gambia.

title: et gambisk kaos...
text:
moro å gå rundt å se men ikke så altfor mye å bruke penger på;-)
Var gla vi hadde kjentmann med for markedet er en salig labyrint med utallige boder og MYE folk!

title: Wszystko w jednym miejscu
text: Fantastyczny targ z wyrobami rękodzieła regionalnego. Za niewielkie pieniądze, można zostać właścicielem pięknych wyrobów z drewna rzeźbionych na miejscu lub też tradycyjnych strojów gambijskich, koszy z baobabu, batiku itp

title: OK for a trip
text: The locals proudly say you can buy anything at this market.  But it looks more like a car boot sale than any market we are used to.  The crowds and stalls might look intimidating, but the locals are harmless (if overfriendly).  Personally, I was not impressed, but others might want to try the experience.

title: Look at all markets.
text:
Banjul market is great and really colourful but if you are in Kololi, Serrekunda is as good if not better. Also, have a look at the market at the top of the Senegambia strip. All prices are negotiable and don't be intimidated by the hard sell. Be in control.
Clothes can be made at very reasonable prices. Make a fair price that you feel you want to pay. If it's refused, walk away without being rude. You will get what you want .
Give it a try.

title: Fargerikt på markedet i Serrekunda
text: Serrekunda er Gambias største by og har ett stort marked som ikke er så 'turistifisert' som det i Banjul. Fantastisk utvalg i bla stoffer av alle slag til en rimelig penge. Ellers er det mye morsomt å se. For ikke å snakke om folkelivet.

title: what an eye opener!
text: this market is nothing like uk markets,and you need a strong stomach with most of it,if you like haggling then you"ll love it, seeing how Gambian people live and work in these markets is a right eye opener and you really appreciate how clean and tidy uk markets are.

title: Kaos på markedet
text: Å besøke marked i Banjul Gambia er en prøvelse.Det er skittent, støvete,masse selgere som vil ha tak i deg og det er ingenting å kjøpe for oss fra Europa, Pass på lommeboken og mobilen.Det er trengsel overalt.Det beste er å gå sammen med en lokal guide,da finner du ihvertfall tilbake hvor du kom fra.Aldri mer dit.

title: You should go!
text: Fun, fun, fun! Lots of great shooping, African clothes, drums  and gifts to bring home. Banjul is a small city and easy to get around. The beaches are fantstic, cheap hotels. Keep in mind that Gambia is a muslim country and it`s wise to dress properly in public areas. Friendly People.

title: Great Gambian experience!
text: large African market where you can find almost everything! It is large, so if you are worried about getting lost in the maze it might be a good idea to take a guide along. It is much less hectic and overcrowded than Serrekunda market and most of the alleyways are quite wide. Large craft market that carers for tourists, but  more selection and cheaper than most others I have visited. If you like vivid-coloured abstract African paintings, ask in the craft market for Ebrima Jaiteh and other stallholders will point you to his stall where he paints while you watch..

title: You just have to go
text: The market is difficult to describe; it's more of an experience than an attraction.  I visited numerous times over a four month period between September and December while I was living in Serekunda and working in Banjul.   My experience, and the way I was treated by vendors and others, evolved over four months I was there. At the end, although I was never a native, I was no longer a complete outsider or merely a tourist.

title: Senegambia Craft Market
text: This is Africa! expect to be hassled, expect to be cajoled, expect to bargain for items. Always be smiley and pleasant, ideally the first time you visit look only, do n't touch or even ask prices. Reflect on what you want and return another day, then look and touch ! The products are cheap anyway but always barter, excellent fabric, wood carvings and jewellery.

title: Local craftsware as usual
text: The craft market is nearby the "Strip" and you find all craft workers concentrated on one spot. So not many sellers borders you on the beach and in the streets.

title: Leuk
text: Hier maken ze allerlei handwerkjes. tafelkleden,doeken,beelden en sieraden bijvoorbeeld op de traditionele manier

title: hassled
text: would of loved to of stayed and shopped here as such beautiful things, but was hassled too much and to afraid to look. if they didn't keep pestering you ,would og bought things, as it was we just left with nothing

title: Do it and try it
text:
Try this craft market, nice people and they have it all, good prices with quality products.
Visit stand number 56 - ask for Rake - Quality products and good prices.

title: leuk!
text: erg leuke markt. Je gaat er zoals je vaker kunt lezen nooit met lege handen naar huis. En als je met meer naar huis gaat dan dat je dacht te willen kopen, dan heb je teveel betaald ;-) maar iedereen wil graag iets verkopen! het kost allemaal niets, dus al is het maar een gezellig gekeurd bamboo armbandje, neem het gezellig mee!

title: Loop je nooit zonder iets weg
text: Vriendelijk verkopers van eigen gemaakte houten dingen. Je bent altijd welkom om een hapje mee te eten tijdens de lunch, wat ik heb gedaan. Kom zeker een keertje terug voor nog meer moois.

title: not your typical market
text: A bit hectic but interesting, noisy  but friendly, some of the stall holders tried their very best but alas not all were successful

title: Good experience
text:
Very busy and bustling market, lots of stalls selling, fruit/veg products, fabrics souvenirs and local craft items.
Be prepared for the selling culture and to haggle down the prices of items.

title: What an afull place
text: Not only they pretend to make it by themselves (all is imported from abroad) they will surround you and all at the same time try to drag you to their shop (often arguing with you) that they have what you want (even though I say nothing what I am looking for). If you want a souvenir then go in there in group with something on your mind and leave quickly or you can but at shops.

title: Leuke markt met lokale handnijverheid
text: Een ruime keuze van lokaal gemaakte houtsnijwerk, sieraden en textiel. Flink onderhandelen is gebruikelijk.

title: Leuke markt
text: Leuke kleine markt om even over heen te lopen. Jammer dat je door alle verkopers aangeklampt wordt om iets te kopen. Daardoor ben je het snel beu en ben je weer snel weg.

title: Silly prices African craft market
text: A good selection of arts and crafts, some nice pieces and some not so nice.  The prices are ridiculous at the offset coupled with pushy overzealous sellers.  These things cost pittance to make in comparison to the retail.  Their is a premium to pay as a foreigner and this is exploited relentlessly by sellers trying to sell goods at far beyond their worth.  You can haggle but you will never be able to pay a fair price.  If you crave attention and have money is not a concern then you will like this place and they in turn will love you.

title: SENEGAMBIA CRAFT MARKET
text: Senegambia Craft Market is right on the beautiful tourist strip at Kololi.  To get there, head down the Bertil Harding Highway southbound until you get to the Senegambia Junction.  The Highway and Junction are bitumen roads straight from Banjul Airport, which really helps as many roads are not surfaced in Gambia.  The Craft Market is right on the crossroads and surrounded by Restaurants such as the excellent Gaya Art Café on the highway and popular African Queen Restaurant just around the corner near Totties Nightclub.  The Craft Market is in a thriving tourist area and there you will find many locally made souvenirs to buy and bring home while stopping off to have a drink or meal in the area on the way to or from Kololi Beach.  You can watch the wood carvers making traditional African masks and ornaments.  You may see sand painters at work, buy some art or hand-made jewellery, try some local food, buy fruit and juice, and see tailors sewing on treadle sewing machines making pretty sun dresses for women and children as well as traditional African clothing.  You can even have a tailor make you an outfit, and I have had a made-to-measure dress or two made there myself.  I can personally recommend Fatou Jagne who has a tailor’s business in the market as that is where I had my first traditional African outfit made-to-measure on a trip to Gambia.  Perhaps you will even catch some djembe players in action or just buy one of these beautifully made traditional drums to take home.  I’ve seen many wrapped up going through the departures queue at Banjul Yundum Airport.  The musicians are not there all the time, but the carvers who make the djembe drums might just show you how to play one if you want to try.  Prices there vary slightly and the traders can be haggled with but please do be polite and reasonable as they have overheads to pay, families to support and “hand-made” in any part of the world takes time.  Don’t forget that materials cost money too.  Their art and crafting is their job not a hobby and they are all very nice people keen to please.  One wood carver made me a wooden fish ornament for my brother while I watched, though fish were not his usual thing to carve.  The people working there are open to suggestions and keen to help.  The thing I like about it being situated right on Senegambia Junction is that at the side of the Craft Market there is a police checkpoint and the officers there will ensure that no tourist is hassled of harassed.  It’s one of my favourite spots in Gambia and I stay in the Kololi area frequently.

title: Leuk om een markt in Afrika te bezoeken
text: De markt in Banjul een grote verscheidenheid aan artikelen, groenten, vlees, vis, maar ook kleden huishoudelijke spullen een heel veel toeristische artikelen, waaronder prachtig houtsnijwerk.

title: Market Trip
text: Go very early in the morning and there is not to much hassling, very dirty and noisy, once in a lifetime visit never to be repeated again.

title: Originele afrikaanse markt
text: Moet je van houden met heel veel kleine straatjes en een keur aan tentjes. Wel op je portemonnee letten.

title: Market
text: A very busy market place with everybody selling everything, nice experience. Barter! barter!! barter!!!

title: An experience not to miss.
text: As the title says, this is a not to be missed experience.  Allow yourself plenty of time, it is a maze and you will be sharpening up your bartering skills before you know it. Don't just look at the tourist areas, have a look at the food market as well, Tesco's will never seem the same again. Remember not to show too much money or it will seriously affect your bartering power.

title: An interesting ethnic experience but not necessarily a pleasant one
text: Banjul market is a crowded rather insanitary tradilitonal African market. You will need to be firm to avoid "bumsters" trying to act as go-betweens and consequently hiking the prices for their own unseen commission while expecting a tip form you afterwards. Most of what is on sale is poor quality Chinese produce. Watch your personal belongings in the narrow alleyways and be sure to take a very tough line in bartering in the unlikely event that you see something worth buying.

title: Leuk en rustig
text: Als je in het toeristische gebied verblijft, is een uitstapje naar Banjul heerlijk. Je kunt het "authentieke" Gambia zien en hier laten de mensen je wel meer met rust. Zo af en toe word je wel aangesproken maar erg storend is het hier niet.

title: markt
text: Leuk om te zien hoe de lokale bevolking hun boodschappen doen,maar de markt in Serrakunda is veel groter en ook heel wat drukker...

title: Banjul Market
text:
Bustling and colourful ,friendly and interesting ,but the stallholders will do Anything to make a sale,and will chat for ages.
We went with a guide and were surprised how many aunts sisters and cousins he had running stalls . When we joked about it he said 'we Gambians are ALL family at heart '

title: drukke lokale markt
text:
leuke lokale markt waar veel dingen te koop zijn
het beste kan je hier met een gids heen gaan,
het is er erg druk en iedereen wil wat aan je verkopen.

title: THE REAL GAMBIA
text: Banjul market is a bustling and noisy place which some tourists are not really prepared for as they approach the experience with their own country's mindset.  If people want to see the country as it is, an open mind is needed.  Here is the real Gambia and an active one where people are putting a lot of effort into earning a living.  Gambians are hard working people.  There is no state benefits system such as that in the UK, so the people in Gambia are very resourceful and productive.  The tourists really need to support their enterprise.  Comparing it to shopping experiences in the tourists' home country is unfair and unrealistic.  Tourists know the price of goods in their home country but many are not willing to pay the price when they go there and even expect to under-pay.  They see the local traders as "husslers" though they are just trying to make a living and they put a lot of efffort into it.  I would encourage tourists to support local industry, but also to do as they do at home - shop around!  Get friendly with a local person who knows where the bargains are.  Gambian ladies are always good to know and helpful, telling people where to find the best price for something they want to buy.  Banjul market is good, but also try Senegambia Craft Market on the Bertil Harding Highway.

title: Interessant, aber nichts für empfindliche Europäer...
text: Ursprünglich hatten wir vor den Royal Albert Markt auf eigenen Faust zu erkunden - waren dann aber glücklicherweise mit unserem Taxifahrer unterwegs. Er hat uns herum und auch wieder heraus geführt. Die Die Hitze und der intensive Fischgeruch in den schmalen, z.T. überdachten Gängen sind nichts für zart besaitete Gemüter. Wer einen Blick ins Schlachthaus geworfen hat, freut sich wieder auf die dicke mürrische Verkäuferin an der heimischen Fleischtheke...

title: An experience
text: Very noisy and at times smelly.  Bustling and active.  Every thing you need is there somewhere!  Well worth a vist.

title: Viele Stände, viele Souvenirs
text:
Der Market scheint vor allem für Touristen zu sein, es gibt unendlich viele Souvenirstände mit den immer gleichen Sachen. Allerdings kann man zusehen wie sie gemacht werden, alles Handarbeit also. Die Gassen sind sehr eng zwischen den Ständen, was dort Durchkommen erschwert.
Alles in allem mit dem anschließendem Bootshafen das Interessanteste in Banjul.

title: its an experience
text: There has been a lot of work done to stop this being such a nightmare for tourists from what I understand, we had our taxi driver with us but did not feel in the least bit intimidated. If it were like shopping in Asda......there would be no point!! relax and enjoy....

title: wouldnt go again
text: for some people it may be a great experience but personally i felt like it wasn't something they wanted us to see. ive been to many locals markets while travelling a few years ago, but i dont think the locals want you there so it just makes it uncomfortable for both parties. my suggestion just dont bother going...or just drive past it.

title: well worth a visit
text:
a trip to banjul market is an eye opener if you have never visited an African market before.
you can buy almost anyting you want , but remember to haggle.also take a guide with you or you may be a long time finding your way out

title: As hectic as ever
text: If you've been here before and feel confident about bartering, there really is no need to have the taxi driver come with you. However, if it's your first time you may feel less intimidated if you have a little 'help.'

title: market
text: Al ways go to the market take local person with you this way you don;t get overcharged and they are very helpfull at bartering for taxi ect

title: Artwork
text: I bought some great artwork and the vendors were a lot more layed back than those in other areas. I found lots of examples of unique pieces of canvasses and the locals were happy to make alterartions to some of the leather goods I purchased. I would say its a nice place to pass through rather than spend a extended period.

title: ook beesten hebben recht op een fijn leven
text:
Dit park is de bezichtiging niet echt waard.
De natuur is oke met hier en daar een aap,  maar een groepje bavianen die in een veel te kleine kooi leven, waarvan er 1 ergens achter de pelikanen(die ook opgesloten zitten in een kooi zonder water) in een soort grote bench wordt gehouden omdat hij gek is geworden(volgens 1 van de gidsen)en twee groepen hyena's die ook zonder water in een smerige omgeving moeten leven is echt niet meer van deze tijd en dit mag gewoon niet.
Ga er niet heen en als je van dieren houd kom er dan niet eens in de buurt want het is hartverschurend.
ik ga zeker alles op alles zetten om deze dieren daar vandaan te halen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Lovely nature reserve (its not a zoo!)
text:
Abuko is a wonderfully intact piece of tropical forest, amongst the otherwise heavily populated Serrekunda area. Some reviewers seem to be under the impression this a zoo, it's not! There is a small animal orphanage at one end of the reserve but its a desperately sad place and not a reason to visit.

I enjoyed wandering the narrow paths seeing birds, lizards and monkeys (you will see them if you walk slowly and quietly). The Darwin field centre is an excellent vantage point to see lots of wading birds and birds of prey as well as Nile Crocodiles.

The guides are knowledgeable and well worth taking along on an initial visit. I agree with the previous reviewer who advised taking water with you, it's quite a long way to do the full reserve circuit and the heat is sapping. The reserve doesn't get much funding so facilities are basic, but I loved it for being so quiet without lots of other people around.

I would recommend Abuko more to the serious nature lover who will get more from it than someone who expects to be entertained and see an animal every 2 minutes. For me, taking time was rewarded by getting to see amazing species like the Giant Kingfisher close up. I enjoyed it so much I actually went twice during my week in The Gambia.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Good for bird spotters
text: A pleasant outing, with lots of opportunities to spot fantastic bird life in the mature undergrowth. Our guide was knowledgeable but a bit uninspiring. We were sorry we didn't see crocs from the lookout point across the pool, and were disappointed and saddened by the dirty-looking 'animal orphanage' - even if they did have hyenas and pelicans. The refreshment point was a bit dull, leaving us exposed to the entreaties of the stallholder nearby.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A cancelled trip
text: I had booked Birds and Breakfast in England before I read a TripAdviser review which said it would be better to go to Abuku with a specialkist guide. The trip was cancelled so I followed advise from TripAdviser and had the most wonderful time using a local professional guide. I also discovered The University of Warwick (probably LifeSciences) have been working at Abuku for some years as part of a research programme. The little booklets are excellent and well worth the money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Take a drink with you
text:
It's very hot take some water with you.
Lots to see as you walk with your guide.
Binoculars were a God send.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: definitely worth a trip but probably just the once is enough...
text: we visited abuku in january with our 7 year old son, he loved it once we had actually found where the animals were, they keep the animals quite far from the entrance to the park, we declined the guide and walked a massive circle for nearly an hour to arrive back at the entrance having found nothing, we got our directions then took another 20 minute walk into the bush (get the guide at the entrance its worth it) we eventually came to 2 large enclosures one with lots of baboons going wild for the nuts we had purchased to feed them and another breed of monkey in the other and green monkeys all around us roaming free with the escapee (a baby baboon that refused to go back into the enclosure) i think there was around 5 different species of monkey/baboons in total as well as a monitor lizard we had passed on the way in.. after our talk from the keeper she guided us over to the final enclosure where the hyenas were having an afternoon nap, they were huge and there was also vultures in the enclosure, my boy was mesmerised,....... after a rest stop at the tuck shop for ice cold drinks we haggled ourselves a nice bargain on a wood carved ornament and headed our way to the exit... all in all was a very memorable day and so glad we went however it is not very interesting until the final moments of the park when u reach the animals.... am i glad i went? yes definitely and would recommend it too, but only once! so will i be returning? in a word,,, no.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: where are the animals?
text: Abuko is no more what it used to be. Only few animals, everthing in a bad condition. Since the "president" Jammeh moved the most interesting animals to his private zoo in Kanilai, Abuko has lost many of its attractions. Nobody would officially admit, but this is what happened. So if you want to see a lion, better visit your local zoo :-(

text: Good outing for a few hours to pass the time but not a great deal to do, was talked about that Abuko would be getting a revamp but nothing as yet.

text: Saw lots of different monkey along with the hyena's - different spieces of plants on the walk around the forest, went a couple of times at different times of day, many vultures when I went around 6.pm and they were feeding the hyena's!!

text: En mi humilde opinión, es mil veces más interesante conocer a los gambianos.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Monkeys!!
text: Don`t miss this park on your trip to The Gambia-so much fun. The monkeys are very friendly-not vicious at all. They climb up you, sit on your shoulders etc as you feed them monkey nuts. So many monkeys!  Book the trip with the RSPB men on Bakau beach (under white umbrella by Calypso Restaurant) if you want to enjoy spotting the birds as well as well as knowledge of the local monkeys. If not then go with the tour guides opposite the Ocean Bay Hotel. They charged us 20 quid which included the taxi & full mornings entertainment plus relaxing time sat under the African sun shades on the beautiful beach next to the park.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: a must
text: great place for a day out ,dont forget your camera,great to have a guide to take you to the best locations

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A little dissapointing
text: We spent about an hour here but overall were rather dissapointed, a nice walk through the forest, a couple of monkeys, and some sleeping hyenas, not much else!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Fantastic
text: Such a beautiful place to spend some time. We went in the early morning and only saw one other couple for the majority of the time we were there. However, on our way back out there were huge groups arriving. I would definately recommend going independantly with your own guide rather then with a tour company in a large group. We saw a huge variety of birds and ther were certainly some very enthusiastic bird watchers there with all the high tech binoculars, telescopes, cameras etc. We also saw a couple of crocodiles and lots of monkeys. Halfway round there is an animal sanctuary where they house animals that have been removed from locals who have bought them to entertain tourists for a charge. There was a very friendly monkey that sat on my knee and played with my hair. You can buy peanuts to feed to the monkeys. We absolutely loved our time here and spent a good 3 hours wandering around spotting monkeys and birds. From what I remember it cost approx 50d (£1) each to get in.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Peacful, beautiful and easy to see the birdlife
text: My guide, Francis Gomez, led me through the reserve pointing out the local birdlife.  Within minutes we had seen a dozen or more species I'd never seen before and over the three hours I was there, he was helpful, friendly and informative.  He helped me see the species unique to the site which I probably would have missed without him.  Admission to the reserve is very cheap but a guide will cost you about £20 upwards, depending how long you want to stay.  Apart from the birds, there's a chance you might spot a croc and definitely monkeys.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not very interesting
text: personally I was dissappointed, I did not see any wildlife except the caged ones and all i got was hassle from people trying to sell me woodcarvings. I found it boring an not as advertised. I would say go out and look around yourself and you see more but don,t rely on local bumsters to show you.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Beautiful but only for bird lovers
text:
We arrived at Abuko having heard and read quite a lot about it. It is better to come here early in the morning, not around 11am like we did since most of the animals are sheltering from the heat and crocodiles are swimming closer to the bottom of the pond.

The few monkeys we saw were not scared of humans, this is because they are used to humans feeding them. People saying it was great to feed wild monkeys probably have not been to a safari or national park before. Infact you are encouraged to buy peanuts for the monekys. And the zoo in the middle is apparently kept there so tourists can atleast see something in the reserve if nothing else. It is expensive to run these reserves and you can see that in the health of the hyenas and monkeys. The place was grand back in the day with lion(s) and other animals, when the founder Mr.Brewster was alive but now has deteriorated a little. The president's zoo is better funded and has more animals.

Saying that, we had a lovely walk around the area and saw some birds. Since we were not bird watchers or bird lovers, we just enjoyed the different varieties without knowing what they were :-)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Very upsetting
text: Very dirty and hot, open stalls with blood dripping meat flung over make shift stalls, covered in  hunfreds of flies, second hand clothes stalls and ladies selling fish and veg again everything covered in flies,not for the fainthearted

title: a must see market
text: this is a very eye opening place and certainly a busy one. i didnt enjoy the fish and meat part of the market because of the smell and to many flys

title: Good place to walk around and get a good bargain.
text: Banjul Market is mainly a craft market with loads of wooden items, paintings, fabrics and similar products. I would recommend going with a guide or a local taxi driver because they can help you barter for items and lead you to the right section if you are looking for a particular item. Banjul market is better than Serekunda if you are looking for gifts however if you want fabric I would recommend going to Serekunda instead because you tend to get better deals on fabrics in Serekunda.

title: a rabbit warren
text: It was quite dark inside like a rabbit warren, but the stall holders were very helpful. If they didnt have what you wanted, they knew someone who did! Worth a visit just for the experience.

title: lots to see
text: crafts you can do or watch tie and dye being done and then have a  chance to purchase any of the goods. wood crafts are excellent and an art in there selves.

title: Well Worth a Visit
text:
We used a Green tourist taxi and went on our own as opposed to going via organised tour guide. We like to do our thing in our own time.

The taxi cost 700 dalassi £14, the driver stayed with us all the time and walked us around the market. Which was great because a.) he knew his way around so we did not get lost & b.) he made sure that we did not get hassled, he also explained to us the way the market runs and explained what the produce was that was on sale.
 He then walked us along the beach to the port and back via the fishing village.

A big eye opener on how they live and just how poor they really are.

title: Great place to make friends
text:
The market traders are great people to get to know. I take their photographs whenever I go there but only after asking permission.
The vital part is to give them copies of the photos on your return.
There are some very beautiful people there.
A modelling agency could fill their books.
Watch out for the wheelbarrows!

title: Local market. Must see it.
text:
I good market to start with. There is a bigger one in Serrakunda. You will need a guide that will help you arround on both places.
We recomand that you take a guide and a driver. Then you and the gudie can focus on the trip. No problem with parking etc.
With some tour companies you will get this city tour for free if you book two full day tours.
We can recomand 4*4 south gambia and the safari in senegal.
We used www.bushwhackertours.com with an exellante guide called JJ. We went on four tripps with him. He was very good at adjusting the trip after ours needs.
Well edjucated in history and local coustums.

title: een ander leuk tussendoortje
text: niet slecht maar geef ons maar de serrekunda market.Er is wel iets te zien maar neem een taxi en ga eens naar Bakau fish market of Tanji(zeker te bezoeken

title: nothing great
text: it is nothing great - typcial west african market. but if you have not been to any before, then it is worth a visit. But bargain hard :)

title: Fish section - if you have a strong stomach
text: Exciting place with so  many things to see. The fish section however was a challenge. As there is no cooling, fish are covered with flies and the smell is very very intense.

title: Market
text: The market was extremely clean considering how many stalls there were. It's a must. Lovely people, but you can't buy from them all!

title: Must do
text:
This is a not-to-be-missed experience, the colours, the smells and of course, the people.
Go with a guide.

title: busy busy
text: lots of things to see here, mostly local hand made goods, shopkeepers were nice and chatty, not too much hassle but bartering part of the fun, worth a visit

title: Very local non-touristy
text: Absalutely huge.  We did not stay long as didn't really want to buy. It is packed, smelly and very local. However it is an experience to maybe try!!!

title: Good
text: A lovely little market, but you get hassled ALOT!! Be prepared to have people coming at you from all different directions trying to sell you their goods!!

title: Che posto...
text: Mercato fantastico, quelli che si lamentano di fango e puzza vadano nei grandi centri commerciali...  trovi tutto cio' che riguarda vestiario e tant'altro... Consigliat andare con qualcuno del posto.... Piu' che altro per contrattare meglio... Sai com'e'....:-)

title: Colourful and and Busy
text:
Very busy and colourful, and very smelly (not for the faint hearted)
The craft part at the back of the market is full of stalls selling local crafts but haggle the prices are high.

title: 3 Main Markets at Banjul Market
text:
Fish Market
Art & Crafts Market
Fruit & Veg Market

All reasonably close to each other and worth asking for local prices before entering any of the markets for a fair price.

title: a busy bustling local market full of colour
text: Banjul Market is a large busy,very hot market,where you really need a guide to take you round,to avoid getting too much attention,and to help with bartering and to find your way round.Theres a lot of local colour,some of the fish/meat stalls can be a bit aromotic but this all adds to the excitement of being in an African market,thats more for locals rather than a tourist trap.This is a great stop off if you are visiting Banjul for a taste of local life with friendly smiling stall holders all trying to sell their goods to you.

title: Overroepen
text: Een bezoek duurt maximaal 10 minuten, waar je één krokodil kan aanraken, en dan loop je rond een pool van zo'n 100 andere krokodillen. Een beetje zielig en echt goed onderhouden lijkt het zeker niet

title: Okay
text: There was nothing worth writing home about. Just a bunch of zonked crocodiles which wasn’t really my idea of interesting but was recommended by one of the locals. A bit overpriced but thankfully negotiable. It’s better suited for families, I’m sure children would enjoy the experience more.
