title: An experience
text: We did not realise when we booked this trip that the crocs are roaming free. We enjoyed the experience of being up close, touching and sitting on one of them. It was a very small place and a quick trip.

title: Give it a miss
text:
Highly overrated and a real tourist con as has been the case for a long time 
The crocodile that you are able to feel is heavily drugged.
A total waste of time.

title: nice place to visit
text: the beach around this restaurant is great, very quiet and beautiful. We only had drinks here but we enjoyed the quiet and lack of people who want to sell you little knickknacks. the crocodiles were sleeping, we sadly missed the feeding. It would be nice if they had a note somewhere when they will feed the crocodiles, otherwise a nice place to be

title: Stroke a crocodile!
text:
Sacred and historic crocodile pool stocked with West African crocodiles. Crocodiles are well fed and used to being approached by humans. Informative museum.
Need a guide to find as not signposted from the road.

title: Intressant möte
text:
Utan att ha bokat något så tog vi en taxi till denna krokodilpark. Vi gick runt i deras museum som kanske inte höll den standard som vi är vana vid på ett museum men en hel del intressant information fanns där. 
Väl framme vid krokodilerna så fick vi en man som följde med oss och informerade glatt om alla krokodiler. Ju mer vi frågade desto gladare blev han och berättade gärna allt han visste. 
Spännande att luta sig halvvägs in i en krokodils gap när den låg och solade sig samt att få klappa dem lite i deras vila. 
Väl värt ett besök. Inträdet kostade 100 dalasi per person.

title: Lots of crocs!!!
text:
Loads of crocs & can get really close to some. Difficult to find but just ask a local.
Small museum on local culture.

title: Wonderful
text: Excellent food, great staff and a beautiful location.  The seafood is wonderful, home grown herbs and salads, good wine and garlic bread to die for!  Live music by two talented guys made the evenings special.

title: Few Crocodiles
text: Overhyped- has to travel a long way to see a few lazy crodiles. Everywhere busters inside and out hassling you to touch the crocodile etc for money. Never leaves you alone

title: Was determined not to go
text: Before leaving the UK this was one place I had made up my mind I definitely wasn’t going. However, we booked a last minute day trip - and this was included so I decided to brave it. I wasn’t aware of the museum at the start so that was nice and very interesting addition. Particularly enjoyed the instruments which our guide said I was allowed to have a go on. On the walk from the museum to the crocodile pond there’s a very interesting tree trunk formation which you can walk inside. Don’t miss it. I was so busy walking and talking to the guide I didn’t realise til I was right upon the crocodiles! I thought my heart would stop. They were laying across the bank, motionless with their mouths wide opened (this is how they cool off). There were some others with their mouth closed and the pool guide invited us to come stroke them. It took me over 15 minutes of coercion to gently touch one with my finger. The guides are really good, patient and knowledgeable. There’s a little gift shop there. I found it impossible to relax at all whilst there as I was so scarred but once I’d left a sense of adrenaline overcame me and I couldn’t believe I had braved it. Guide took a great photo of the inside of one of the opened mouths. Good, clean toilet.

title: Té commercieel.
text: Je bezoek duurt 5 minuten. Een kuil met veel krokodillen en één exemplaar dat je kan aanraken. Voor iemand die nog nooit een krokodil in de zoo bij ons gezien heeft, ok.

title: Tourist trap
text: It's nice if you have kids but it's a bit of a tourist trap.  It looks like the crocodiles are drugged.

title: Crocodile dundee
text:
Ok, het is echt een enorm gave ervaring om een krokodil aan te raken, eerlijk is eerlijk, maar toch was ik persoonlijk niet erg onder de indruk van de crocodile pool. 

Misschien net even iets te klein qua omgeving voor mij. Bij de entree heb je eerst een museum, daarna zie je echt een paar enorme grote bomen, en dan kom je direct bij een kleine vijver met een tig aantal krokodillen die lekker liggen te zonnebaden. Voelde allemaal wellicht wat onnatuurlijk aan, ondanks dat het van oorsprong wel natuurlijk is. Komt hoogstwaarschijnlijk ook door het hek waar je langsloopt richting de krokodillen...

Voor de gambianen overigens een heilige plek en positief gericht op het vinden van juiste partners en het krijgen van gezonde kindjes! Die gedachtegang is wel mooi natuurlijk!😊

title: Small and uncomfortable
text: The crocodiles were small and just everywhere. Some you could pet/touch and some you shouldn’t go near. It was really small there and not big at all. Wouldn’t have visited it if it wasn’t on the tour we went on.

title: Don’t miss this
text: What an experience! Very cheap to get in, lovely little museum at the start, the crocodiles roam around, I touched one!!! Our guide was brilliant telling us all about the crocs and it was really interesting, I’m so glad we visited, highly recommended

title: Worth a visit
text: The park was within walking distance of our hotel however we incorporated this into a tour day with Abilie Jobe( his stand is opposite Ocean Bay Hotel he is a great guide excellent English speaker very knowledgable and much cheaper than the tour operators price) I got to stroke a crocodile. The museum at the park is very interesting 100 Dalasi just over a £1.

title: visit
text: Walked on the beach to see the pool. Crocodiles were too sleepy to take any notice. We're not hungry.

title: NOT for faint hearted!
text:
An amazing experience that i do not think you can do anywhere else on earth and 100% NOT in Europe!!!

Get upclose and personal with one of the most deadliest animals on earth.

You literally ENTER the home of these crocs that walk around freely, just one rule DO NOT touch them by the head area if you want to come out in one piece! 

I cannot recommend this place highly enough! Also there is a museum that is really educational.

title: Fascinating Place to Visit
text:
We were brought here by our guide for the day. A fascinating place to visit where the sleepy crocs come out of the water to relax in the sun. They look very relaxed and seem used to visitors touching them.
There's a small museum to visit on the site and some unusual birds to observe within the grounds of the pond.
We could also see the local ladies working on the adjoining allotments where they draw water from a well and then use a bucket with holes in the bottom to water their crops - slow hard work!

title: A great day
text: We had a lovely time in Abuko, our guide was great and we saw loads of birds and monkeys... and even a snake! The one bad point is the awful 'zoo' in the middle where they house baboons, hyenas and turtles. It absolutely stinks and the animals are totally miserable. I refused to give any money for that.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not worth a visit
text: What a shame this reserve has been allowed to go to rack and ruin.  Everything very shabby.  We were told that it used to be a wonderful place when it was first set up.  We saw very little and were very disappointed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great for the nost part...till you get to the animals in cages...
text:
Although I thought Abuko was wonderful for the most part, (we saw a crocodile, a bushbuck and several species of monkeys and birds) I was dismayed to see the hyenas in captivity, also baboons and some other animals, all in cages. I was told that the baboons are orphaned (though it was a whole family), and also some of the other animals, but that the hyenas are just an exhibit. There also used to be a lion there but it escaped. Apparently they have links with the local zoo, and some of the animals live in captivity always. There is no need for this - visitors come to see wildlife in its natural state, not kept in a prison. The hyenas were pacing up and down i.e. exhibiting stereotypical behaviour, which was not good to see at all.

Also although there are notices up saying not to feed the wildlife however friendly it is, people (and one of the guides!) were openly feeding the monkeys peanuts, thus habituating the monkeys to humans, and causing them to lose their natural skills. Abuko should actively be fining people for doing this and the guides should be sufficiently educated so as not to do this. 

For this reason I have given this reserve a 3-star rating, otherwise it would be a 4 or 5.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: The smell
text:
It is a long walk with little of interest from the main gate to the first lodge which is twinned with the University of Warwick (Birdwatching), A bit interesting as an alligator was watching a wading bird and we watched the alligator...yawn!!...  A short further walk through thicker overgrowth brings you to the heart of the reserve. Staff are always needing money to feed the animals... A very sad affair, as the main animals have allegedly been transported to the presidents old village  zoo.  You are left with the stench from 5 hyenas and 20 vultures who constantly watch the few monkeys that surround the area. 
There are a few captive monkeys to feed peanuts to if you want. Most fun was being professionally ambushed by the reserve monkeys on the way out who cleaned us of anything edible.  in conclusion..It was tired, the staff were tired, the animals looked tired...

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Monkey Loving!
text:
I loved Abuko, it has a little something for everyone. 

It is quite a walk, the less mobile may want to give this a miss, but when you get to the end, the tamer monkeys are there to entertain
and steal the nuts you have just bought for them! Keep the plastic bag out of slight or they will grab at it! 

It was fantastic to feed wild monekys. This made the trip well worth it. 

If you drove to the park, like I did, as a bit of advice, when you get to the cafe, go visit the hyenas and stuff, but don't go through the past with the exit sign over it. Go back the way you came, otherwise you end up a 15 minute walk down a dusty busy road from where you first started!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A must.
text: Had an amazing time visiting this centre, our guide was most informative. Paid 100 Dallas I on entry, but tipped our guide for his work.

title: Lovely
text:
A really enjoyable visit to the crocodile pool, thanks to my local guide from Gambia friendly tours..
I will definately come back next time i visit.

title: Интересно.
text: Посетили ферму во время обзорной экскурсии. Представляет собой небольшой заиленный пруд, где живут крокодилы и небольшой парк из диковинных для нас растений( огромные баобабы, хлопковое дерево и т.д.). Когда мы пришли, крокодильчики ждали на берегу, и каждый из нас мог контактировать с этими  "милыми существами” на сколько хватит фантазии и смелости. Я тихонечко подержалась за хвост и впечатлений мне хватило.

title: Amazing to stroke them
text: Went along to the pool and quite a few crocodiles. Texture of them is very strange but well done to the staff and guide. An experience well worth it

title: Great hidden gem
text:
Great place to visit, has a small museum with aincent masks and musical instruments together with the history of The Gambia.
A short walk and your at the pool, surprisingly small but has lots of crocodiles. You actually get the chance to touch and feel a real crocodile 
This is a charity so all donations are welcome, a few locals selling their souvenirs but no hard sell
or hassle 
Well worth a visit

title: Average
text: lots of crocodiles but not a lot of movement. Asked for extra money to support the crocodiles. Take hand wash with yu as you are asked to touch the crocodiles.

title: alles ok
text:
Die Fahrt dort hin Afrika style ,wie soll ich das erklären.
sehenswert um Banjul.Die Führung gut.soviel Krokodil Zähne die sie dort verkaufen können nicht von diesen Gehege stammen

title: Interesting visit
text:
Good way to pass a couple of hours strolling tgrough tge museum and getting to know a bit about the history of Gambia. The crocodiles are fed twice a day and happy to be stroked and photographed following the guides instructions. 
There are around 100 crocodiles that roam free in and around the pool area, so watch where you walk. There are also lizards roaming around and a fascinating Elephant tree. Well worth a visit.

title: The trip was as good as the crocs
text:
We met a lovely person on the beach named JoJo that took us on the trip. 

It started with a walk (15 minutes) through "the real africa" were the Gambian people live their day to day lives. 
This walk was a big "eye-opener" and gave me and my girlfriend a lot of emotions, to see how they REALLY live. You can't experience that at the hotels. 

Then we arrived at a small museum where we learned about The Gambia. And after that we meet the reptiles. It's crazy how close you can get to these beasts. 
But it's very safe and the owners are there to comfort you, haha. 
I can really recommend this trip. 

And i want to give a big shoutout to our new friend JoJo. He made our Gambian vacation a lot better.
If you want to experience The Gambia i really recommend you guys to contact JoJo.

title: No merece la pena
text: Lo único interesante del sitio es un árbol precioso de 300 años. Los cocodrilos están hacinados en una pequeña piscina natural, había uno fuera que te dejaban tocar, parecía como drogado, daba pena ver los animales...

title: Crocs....
text: We came here as part of our 6 in 1 day tour.  The little museum was interesting - our guide explained about the musical instruments and tribal culture and then you go to see the pool which is still considered sacred by the locals.  I would question the taking of tourist pictures with the crocs on the bank and suspect that the creatures are doped up in some way to make them docile and allow people to get up close to them.  There were hordes of people milling around when we were there which seemed a little surreal.  Worth seeing for the experience but like I say, I do question the photo taking......

title: Well worth a morning or afternoons visit
text: We had an amazing and extremely knowledgeable guide who's name I'm ashamed to say has completely escaped me. He gave us a wonderful insight into the area's history including the part many of them played during the war for the allies as well as the tribal history of the area. The crocodile park itself is amazing, your literally a few feet from them and if you work with the guides you can actually touch them. Was a shame to see a few tourists not abiding by the guides requests/rules and putting themselves into dangerous situations so please listen to the guides as they are experts with these animals and are extremely aware of keeping them safe too. Make sure you take a bag of lollipops for the local kids too

title: Trip
text: Well worth a visit. Guide there takes you through a bit of a history of Gambia some interesting items on show.

title: Många västafrikanska krokodiler.
text: Inte europeisk klass på djurpark. Lite obehagligt att inte krokodilerna var inhägnade utan låg lösa framför fötterna på en.

title: Krokodiili mesta
text:
Bakaussa lähellä Cape Point-ia sijaitsevassa rokotiilipuistossa n. 100 krokoa. Ennen puistoa pieni museo joka kertoo suppeasti Gambian historiaa. Epäusko valtaa kulkijan lähestyttäessä puistoa, koska tiet ja talot ovat aivan kuin slummia.  Tien päässä on kuitenkin kylläisiä krokoja ja niitä voi taputella jos uskaltaa. Ei hinnalla pilattu jos ei ole ennen krokoja koskenut. Kannattaa ottaa autokuljetus puistolle, n. 5 eskoo per nenä. 
Lazy crocodiles and small museum about Gambia history.

title: Rør ved en krokodille.
text: Gik hen til krokodille parken med lokal guide. Der var 100 krokodiller på stedet. De gik frit rundt mellem os. Vi klappede en af dem (ca. 2 meter lang) på ryggen og løftede på dens bagben. Det skal prøves. Kun 50 kr. i entre.

title: Very cool!!
text: Amazing experience! Never thought I would ever touch a crocodile! They are very relaxed and don't mind people being around. Great value for money

title: Touching Crocodiles
text:
I visited cricodile pool with Black and White tours. There is a little museum which has intetesting history relating to Gambia and tribal culture. The pool itself is fenced off but the crocodiles are together by pool. There are guides based there for different languages. They let you touch crocodiles but dont touch the crocodiles heads. My guide from Black and White took great pictures.
You can buy real crocodile teeth.
An amazing place to visit

title: Enjoyed
text:
Been here a few times when in Gambia with my children . They love it. You get up close with the crocodiles as they move about or lay there resting after been fed on fish . You can see them in the crocodile pool swimming by. 
 Before you get to the crocodiles there is a very intesting museum with history of The Gambia and it’s men who contributed to the war for England . A place with traditional musical instruments and another room with cultural jujus . 
The guides are very good and will take you for photos with the crocodiles. 
I would recommend a visit here when visiting The Gambia .

title: 6 in 1 tour
text: There's probably a few travel operators providing this tour and there's certainly plenty of locals offering a taxi style trip. But mine was booked through our Gambia experience rep and included the crocodile pond and museum tour. These fish eating crocodiles! once fed are quite content to bask in the shade whilst tourists mingle with them and touch their bodies. It's quite surreal and has a complete disregard for elf n safety or so it appears. The museum is small and informative on the history and culture of the country. Other stops include markets and a tea and coffee stop at a waterside lodge and a traditional wrestling match which was fun. A beach stop to a very pretty beach was some drive  and a decent lunch provided. The last stop to a fishing village was cancelled due to time. Travel was in a open top bedford lorry which was also fun, generally a good experience albeit a little expensive.

title: Adventurous
text:
The market in Banjul is worth a trip, just driving thrue Banjul will give you an insight on what an African City means.
Lots of things to see and buy in the market.
It's a real Gambian market, not a tourist trap.

title: Never travel to Banjul, Gambia
text: Extremely dirty muddy place and on top of it  - it is dangerous due to no police or other control. Never eat here and drink only bottled water.

title: Worth visiting
text: Good and cheap gifts.  Can barter with the locals, to get the best price. Well worth visiting the markets.

title: Beautifull market but not if you're alone!
text: Banjul has a beautifull craftmarket where you can buy lots of beautifull craft, such as, batik, woodcarvings, paintings and others. Unfortunatly we where the only ones at the market beacause it was still low season. Everybody is convincing you that they got the nicest shop. Be carefull cause the guides may close a deal with the salesmen and you pay a to high price.

title: Geweldige markt
text: Niet te vergelijken met onze markten. Heel veel mensen veel dieren het is er vies en als je alleen bent zou je zo maar eens kunnen verdwalen.

title: A must experience
text:
Yes it might be overwhelming or even unpleasant at times but to not visit the Albert Market in Banjul would be missing out on the essence of what this place is about. It is a fantastic assault on the sences, best take a local with you and get him to keep you out of the tourist section, no hassel from sellers then as they know you wont want what they sell! 
Dont miss the fish and meat sections.........
Carefull who you point your camera at though, the attention is not always welcome.

title: Weinig diversiteit
text: Als je souvenirs wil, dan kun je die hier halen. Neem wel een gids mee die voor je onderhandelt. Ze hebben houtsnijwerk, schilderijen en batikstoffen.

title: Busy Busy Busy
text: A busy market full of noise and colour, watch out for pick pockets !!!!..... better to take a local tourist guide with you........... you have to barter for everything be prepared to get hassled to buy  but all part of the experience, it can get very hot in the center of Banjul make sure you take water with you

title: Horrible!
text: Very dirty and smelly market...not sure of the exact reason it is included as a place to visit! It was probably for people to shop but believe me, it wasnt worth the stress at all.

title: Leuke toeristenmarkt voor de souvenirs
text: Mocht je op zoek zijn naar leuke souvenirs dan kun je die hier vinden. Elk winkeltje heeft wel hetzelfde maar hierdoor kun je wel afdingen...als je durft!

title: Colour and vibrant
text:
Went round the market looking for fabric.
The market is full of colour and real Banjul life, when going around the market you have some attention. However prepare to be hassled in the craft market, however it is all good fun. If you do not like meat or fish smells avoid this area

title: Nothing special really
text:
We booked a taxi driver for the day & he brought us here to look around. My mom wanted to look at designer bags (which are fake here) but he brought us to the more local-market and we felt kind of uncomfortable in those narrow alleyways between stands and everyone looked at us. It smelled bad, too. He brought us to a stand with leather bags which were nice but I don't like to bargain and to be fair, I don't want a bag in the shape of a voodoo doll when I get back to Holland. So we asked our guide to bring us back to the main street. He didn't know what we meant with designer bags en seemed a bit lost so after two shops (who were nice and airconditioned) we asked to go. 
Prior to this we bought some fabric at a stand where our guide bargained for us so we could buy the nice fabric to be tailored into dresses. We paid 800 dalasi for 2 pieces. We had it tailored at the Senegambia hotel by Aida for 1350 (not each, but in total).

title: Great place but full on!
text:
i loved visiting the markets, they are buzzing so it can be full on at times as everyone tries to sell you things as you are a tourist.  Don't get caught up in this, only pick up things if you are interested otherwise you may find yourself stuck there for a lot longer than you want to be!  make sure you take water as it gets hot walking around the markets during the day with the heat.  

If you aren't one for seeing animals (i.e. butchers/fishmongers) be warned you will come across stalls like this with everything out on the floor.... it's the way it is done so cover your nose and close your mouth to avoid the strong smells.  Just remember you are seeing the reality which is definately in technicolour in this place - Fab!

title: Bumster nightmare
text: Aggressively hassled and harassed by bumsters, security guards and stall holders.  Will never return.

title: WHAT AN EXPERIENCE
text: The local just dont let you get on with just browsing

title: Local flavours - good and bad!
text:
Visiting the local market/souk or whatever they are called are always a must when traveling to exotic places - and the Banjul market as such resembles what you will find across Africa. It is hectic, noisy, smelly - and so interesting!

Obviously you have to fight off the beggars once in a while, but if you go with a determined mind they are not too hard to get rid off. It is not easy to know when you can take a picture and when not - and your eyes see so many things, your camera wishes to bring back home. But mostly you will have to keep those memories in your head to not risk offending the locals. 

If however you shop non-tourist items you will not have to bargain, and the experience will be so much nicer. I brought back plastic dishes, mugs etc. at the ridiculous price of 30-40 euro cents each, and the seller did everything to make me happy finding the exact color and pattern I wanted!

It is however recommended to bring your taxi driver, as you will otherwise find yourselves with a lot of people talking to you only to later claim you own them money for guidance!

title: AN EXPERIENCE
text:
a  busy market full of noise and colour, watch your pockets.
this is where you have to barter for everything,people great, goods great.

title: dirty crowded
text: oh my  god what can you  say  dirty  cheap tatt and  very pressured to buy. Its  almost threatening

title: Worth a visit
text: You do get hassled alot but worth a visit. You can get a local yellow and green taxi there and there are plenty of taxi available to get back to your hotel

title: Disgusting and pushy
text: The market is just plain disgusting. Lots of rotten fish and vegetables being sold, the stench is unbearable. The craftmarket is full of pushy people, just dragging you by your arm into their stores. They say they're offended if you don't look around, but their even worse when you do. We just left.

title: Kesyjä krokotiilejä
text: Hotellilta piti ottaa opas mukaan. 5€ per henkilö. Opas osti lapsille karkkia ja jakoi sitä matkalla. Sisäänpääsy lippu oli oikeasti 100 dalasia eli 2€, sen opas osti. Historia on ilmeisesti gambialaisille tärkeä, koska joka museossa kerrottaisiin vaikka kuinka kauan joka kuvasta jne, museon läpi mennään alueelle. Alue on aika pieni, viidakkomainen polku, muutama iso puu ja sitten krokoja silittelemään. Todella laiskoja krokoja, eivät juurikaan liiku. Ei mikään huippu nähtävyys. Saa aikaa kulumaan lomasta pari tuntia ja 5 eurolla höpötystä joka puusta ja talosta.

title: Lopen tussen levende krokodillen
text: Dit verstopte parkje is een fotojuweeltje. De poel is bezet met rond de 100 krokodillen.  Achter de vijver kun je de daar aanwezige krokodillen aaien, wel eerst vragen aan het personeel.  Zo dichtbij kom je niet vaak

title: super atrakcja dotknąć 2m krokodyla
text: Super atrakcja. Byliśmy w Bakau dzięki miejscowemu przewodnikowi Kincie dotarliśmy tam na piechotę poprzez labirynt delikatnie to nazywając skromnych zabudowań więc jeśli chodzi o zapach krokodyli to dobrze pachną. Obserwacja i dotykanie tych zwierząt było niesamowite i niezapomniane. Nasz przewodnik doskonale się sprawdził byliśmy z nim jeszcze w Monkey Park, na karmieniu sępów i na safarii w Fathala. Jeśli ktoś chciałby skorzystać to +2207796258 kontakt przez whatsapp - tak to tam działa :)

title: Krokodil streicheln
text: Erstes mal ein Krokodile berührt war sehr beieindruckend. Im Teich und auf den Wegen warenüber 20 Krokodile zu sehen.

title: Good
text: Worth a visit but not exceptional. They request a donation for food for the crocs! You can have your pic taken whilst touching them

title: Truly amazing
text: This is a magnificent place that I have been to 3 times. There is an interesting museum documenting a lot of history. Then you go to the pool and there are over 100 crocs just basking in the sun. You can stroke them. Some people just lark about which is really pathetic as these are wild animals. Well fed on fish but still not to be messed with. Some fools think they are Crocodile Dundee and naturally the guides tell those people off. The crocs seemed happy enough to me. It is a marvellous place and I will go back many times

title: Mysigt
text: Liten krokodilpark, men en underbar upplevelse att vara så nära och även kunna klappa dessa varelser.

title: What a great place to visit
text: We were given a tour by the men who look after the crocodiles and what a great team they are showing you all the hiding places that the crocodiles use. A must visit if you are in Gambia.

title: Sömniga krokodiler
text:
Ett hundratal (!?) mer eller mindre sovande krokodiler... 
Visade inget som helst intresse för någotn eller någon.
Turisterna kunde klappa i stort sett obehindrat.

title: Poor crocs and agressive guides
text: Not much to see. Just poor crocs, have no idea how they poison them to keep that calm. Entrance is 100 D, which is ok. But then the so called "guides" will force you to take them for the tips that are 300-400 D (absolutely for nothing). And if you refuse, they gets very agressive and start shouting, including racist abuse. So don"t make them happy, skip this place.

title: Doing the place up nicely
text: Went to see the crocodiles today with my family, the  museum has had work done to it to make it much better for the public and also the crocodile place was having work done to it too. The tour guy was amazing who walked us round and supported us to touch the crocs. What an amazing experience this was thanks so much to everyone who was part of this.

title: Amazing
text:
This place is good value for money, as a small museum is also on site.
I would advise you have a taxi or take an official tour to get there as it is located in the middle of a busy local area and may be difficult to find as there is not much in the way of signage!

title: Heilige krokodillenvijver
text: In Katchikally bevindt zich al meer dan 500 jaar de Crocodile Pool. Het is een bedevaartsoord, veel mensen geloven dat de dieren heilig zijn en dat deze je kunnen helpen bij je vruchtbaarheid. Veel vrouwen wassen zich met het krokodillenwater. De beesten zijn overigens getemd, sommigen zijn zelfs aaibaar.

title: Spannend
text: Je loopt samen met de gids dwars door de krokodillen, ze krijgen elke dag voer, zodat ze niet hongerig zijn. Best wel een aparte ervaring

title: Leuk
text: Voor een heel klein bedrag krijg je een behoorlijke uitleg en mag je de krokodillen aaien. Als je ze gevoederd wil zien worden ga je best rond 16 u.

title: Wild Crocodiles you can touch
text:
The town of Bakau, just 12 km from Banjul, the capital of The Gambia, hosts an interesting site.  A pool with crocodiles, which inexplicably allow themselves to be touched and petted.  The pool is named Kachikally (also Katchically or Katchikali) and belongs to the Bojang family which has been administering it for 500ish years.

The site is promoted to be a sacred pool in which barren women can bath to wash away whatever has been holding them back from conceiving.  After performing the sacred ritual bathing, she is told to remain faithful to her husband and not to shake hands with other men for a year.  Faithfully adherence should bring her a child.  Required elements of the ritual includes bringing “a humble petition” of “Kola-nuts and other small offers” to the Bojang family.

Entering, I was met by a guide who collected my entrance fee and led me about a hundred yards to the pool (after I suggested that I would visit the museum at the entrance at the end of my visit).  The pool and its surrounds are a kind of oasis in the middle of the town.  The approximately 9 acre site is surrounded by trees and swamp-like growth and you quickly forget that you are in the middle of a populous town.  Right in front of the pool lie the main attractions, 2 meter long crocodiles sunning themselves with their mouths wide open (which is their way of keeping cool).  I was the only visitor at the time, but it was startling to see several guides seated just 8-10 feet from these reptiles which strike such fear in southern US States and which generate headlines when their encounters go horribly bad for locals (and often their pets) caught by surprise. 

I took a step closer, and then another one.  Then there I was, bending over and petting a live crocodile, smiling at the camera as my guide took my picture.

As I said, I can’t explain why I became complacent.  It just seemed perfectly natural to wander around the crocodiles, touching them, asking questions, and staring into their gapping, tooth filled mouths.  Their semi-catatonic state made me think that perhaps they were sleeping (though their eyes were open and eerily followed you as you moved around).  I asked my guide about this, and he smiled again (in fact, I think he never quit smiling).  He asked me to get my video camera ready.  He said that they were always alert, and ready to pounce on food to which they would be alerted based on the vibration it would make when it hit the ground.  Sure enough, he tossed a stick, and as you can see in the video in my blog, they jumped when it hit the ground, and only stopped when its smell didn’t register as food.

I have more information about Kachikally in my blog, including a list of reasons you may want to visit and a video of how active the crocodiles are.  The link is in my profile.

title: Lifted the crocodile's legs
text: Health and Safety in Europe wouldn't let you do half the things you can do here. Pose for a photo cuddling a crocodile, lift up its legs & tail - amazing.

title: Crocs
text: I pop for a visit to see the crocodiles each time  in the area ... where else could you do this ?! Defiantly worth a visit , maybe not small children 😕

title: Crocodile pool
text: Place, where you can see crocodiles very close. You are in the same area with the crocodiles. It is little bit scary to be in same area with crocodiles. They move very fast but Charlie is one of the croc,  which you can touch and be with him in same picture. You can touch him behind and one of the worker is very close. They give lots of fish for crocs and that's why they are full and satisfied.

title: Très bonne expérience
text: Très bonne expérience. Le parc n'est pas très grand mais est bien tenu. Il est possible d'approcher de près les crocodiles, toujours sous le contrôle des éco gardes. Il y a également un musée très intéressant sur plusieurs éléments de l'histoire de la Gambie. Il ne s'agit pas de la principale attraction mais si visite vaut le détour.

title: Albert  fish n fly market!?!
text: Although the craft market offers some unusual locally made goods,the rest of the market on the whole,is there to serve the locals with "fresh" local produce.It can be very "aromatic" and hot,very busy with locals "on their missions",but on the outskirts are some very good trading outlets,(all round the city of Banjul),so best to wander or explore and avoid the market early morning.Once ventured never forgotten folks?

title: Lo único interesante de Banjul
text: Banjul es una ciudad inhóspita y dura. No por falta de seguridad, ningún lugar de Gambia resulta inseguro. Sino por la crudeza de la vida que allí se expone a la vista, al olfato y a la sensibilidad  del viajero. El mercado es increíble. Hay que visitarlo. No para comprar (que también, si es que quieres comprar gallinas africanas, zapatos usados, cabezas de cordero, polvo de Baobab, o artesanía diversa..). Es un lugar fuera del tiempo, de una fuerza sensorial imposible de encontrar en la "rica" Europa, y de una humanidad tan auténtica, que te hará pensar, y no podrás olvidar.

title: Busy, crowded, hot and scruffy, but worth a visit
text:
This market mixes local and touristy things to purchase, you are hassled a bit, but no where near as bad as Egypt. The title says it all really, but you do need to bargain hard, as they will just try to get as much from you as they can. We always take our friendly taxi driver with us, who gives us an idea of the price to pay, though he does this away from the vendor as they will accuse him of spoiling their business.
A far better and larger market to get a feel of real Gambia is Brikama, this is a proper local market and you will not be hassled at all, though there are few touristy things here, there is a local craft centre nearby.

title: Take a guide
text: Use the local hotel tourist guide for this very busy and narrow market - its fantastic.  Sharpen your bargaining skills,

title: A vibrant colourful market
text: Take a Government Guide (yellow shirts and a badge) and you can look around freely without any hassle.  Fascinating insite into the Banjul way of life.

title: Africa at its best!
text:
Albert Market is in Banjul on Liberation Avenue - a must for every visitor to Gambia. Very busy, very crowded and typycal African. Most parts of the market are just for the local needs and not covering the typical touristic stuff. 
I really enjoyed the atmophere, smell and sounds. However if you are not used to african Markets at least the fish and meat section may be a very different experience.
One of the few must does in Banjul!

title: Suggested Green shopping - and save a life or two!
text:
Why go to a Gambian market and not buy something? Why not buy something and avoid the hassle of carrying it home? Why not buy something that will make an excellent gift and save a life in the process?
I'm suggesting that you visit Banjul market - go by bush taxi (part of the experience) and when you arrive walk along Old Perseverance Street in Albert Market till you come to the shop of Manneh Suwareh, dealer in 'bednets' - mosquito nets, in other words. The nets are well made locally, come in various shades and styles and make superb, life-saving gifts to your favourite hotel staff, village schools, hospitals or casual strangers. Mosquitoes kill people. We take anti-malarials and tend not to visit during the rainy season. Gambian village houses are built to let hot air out, Sadly, this enables mozzies to fly in. Buy a net, give a gift, save a life. Cost? About 200D - the price of a few drinks, and a fraction of the cost you would pay back home.
Manneh is a lovely man; he won't rob you - and you'll probably get a conducted tour of the market thrown in.

title: great place to stroke a croc
text: I am known for having accidents so my partner was a little apprehensive about going here and allowing me to stroke a croc....what was he worrying about? The park is not that big so easy to walk around and there are a few crocs in the main lake you go to < they get one to come out and allow you up close to stroke it>  definitely an experience

title: Croc park
text: My son and I were apprehensive despite being told that the crocodiles were tame owing to the fact that they are well fed. Nevertheless, the staff were reassuring and lovely. It was a great experience which my son and I thoroughly enjoyed.

title: Extraordinary place to see crocs
text: I brought 2 groups here and they were both really excited to see the crocs in and around the pool. The price has been increased dramatically and the managers are in danger of pricing tourists out of here. The museum is interesting but dated in presentation and rather dusty. Visitors who haven't seen crocs before are invariably impressed with the pool. A must see if you visit Gambia.

title: Amazing to see them up close
text:
Off the beaten track and through a very poor area in Bakou, you get to see a more real side of Gambia on your journey there.

There are dozens of crocs here, most of them down in the pond which is fenced off so you can look down without fear of them approaching or you falling in... There are also 1 or 2 up at the top where the guides allow you to go to close to them and take pictures as well as touch them. Crocs are fed a lot of food on the morning so they are not interested in attacking (or even moving), hence the guides assuring you of your safety (They aren't drugged despite the bad reviews)

Definitely worth a visit with a tourist taxi rather than a big group, there were less than 10 people there when we visited, well worth spending an hour or so there

title: Possibly most unnerving experience ever....
text:
But really glad we did this. 

Go with a local guide. There’s a nice museum at the entrance and a local guide will give you a real flavour of history here and talk about their own tribal histories and customs. 

The walk to the pool itself is interesting - very old tree as well as flora and fauna. 

You suddenly come upon the crocodiles and the first thought is “oh that’s a realistic model” and then you realise the croc next to your foot is alive....

The crocodile keepers are excellent and touching a live croc was something I won’t forget. Which is good because I’m not doing it again either!

This was a real highlight. The animals are well cared for and are not drugged or mistreated. Definitely something to do whilst visiting locally.

title: dazed crocs
text: this is just a small park with crocodiles that look like they are drugged. they don't even hardly move and you can touch them.

title: Interesting and a little scary
text:
Before you enter to the crocodiles zone, you can visit a good museum showing a bit of Gambia's history, and an exhibition of musical instruments and traditional artifacts, it already starts good.
When you leave the museum, you will be located on the surroundings of a natural pool full of crocodiles, some of them resting around, or directly on your path! the guides know them all (at least this is how it looks) and they tell you which ones are dangerous and which are not, even those that you can touch and how to do it.
Maybe they shouldn't be selling souvenirs with crocodiles teeth, it's the only drawback for this attraction, however, I don't think that they kill them for that.

title: Museum and crocodile park
text:
Great little museum, lots of local information, ceremonial masks,instruments.. Was kind if disappointing so short but, worth it.. 
Crocodile park definitely needs investing but, if you can block that thought, its a nice little park.. Guide had lots of information not just about crocs, also fauna and wildlife..able to get close and take pictures guide very patient!!
Nice afternoon out..

title: Leuke en spannend uitje
text: Deze tour hebben wij gedaan, en is een echte aanrader voor avonturiers. Je ziet hoe de krokodillen leven, en hoe ze gevoerd worden. Je kunt ze aanraken/aaien. Er loopt er ook eentje (wellicht wel meer) rond die een poot mist doordat en ander deze heeft afgebeten in een gevecht.Onze kids en wijzelf vonden dit een hele leuke avontuurlijke excursie. Echt een aanrader!!

title: Crocs & A Lesson on The Gambia
text:
Yes you get to see crocodiles. Lots of them. You get to touch a few of them as well. Quite an experience.

What I feel should be mentioned is the little tour of the history of The Gambia as well as the people that you walk through efore getting to the crocs. Its well worth it to get someone knowledgable to take you through the little museum they have there.

No doubt the crocs are the main attraction but why not get a history lesson as well?

I think we paid D100 as an entrance fee. You'd be mad to pass up on this!

title: Great experience and well worth a visit.
text:
Small park area with a central pool containing circa 100 crocodiles. The guides claim they only eat fish and don't touch meat but he wasn't prepared to take the £100 on offer to prove it by swimming across.
The opportunity to get up close and actually touch a crocodile. They do seem very tame but no doubt can 'turn' at any time so be careful. 
There's supposed to be a large albino croc called Charlie present but we didn't get to see him as he only appears at feeding time they say.
Lots of little crocs around out of the pool just basking in the sun. Don't walk off the beaten track though as you could easily stumble upon a nest of eggs with the mother watching over them. There's also a few snakes around so perhaps put on some long trousers for protection.
Small entry fee of 100 Gambian Dalasi (around £1.50)
Nice little museum at the entrance charting some of the history of the area and the influence of the British under colonial rule.

title: Museum en heel veel krokodillen
text: De tweede keer dat wij hier kwamen. Het museum geeft veel informatie over de geschiedenis en cultuur van Gambia. In en om de krokodillenpoel zijn meer dan 100 krokodillen te vinden. Het blijven prachtige beesten, maar het zijn er wel heel erg veel die in deze "opvang" leven.

title: Fun
text:
The little museum at the entrance is very interesting and it was great to see all the crocodiles at the pool.  

It was recommended we visit late afternoon, glad we took that advice as we got to see so many of them!!

title: Amazing
text: wow wow wow loved this . Can’t believe we touched a croc. Amazing and a experience and memory that will last a lifetime

title: Second visit same awesome experience
text: So this was my second visit to the crocodile pool, this time i went with my 8 year old daughter, 6 year old nephew, sister and 2 year old niece. It was a 100 dalasi fee for entry for adults while the kids went in free. We started off with the tour of the mini museum then proceeded to the pool where the crocodiles are. You are allowed to touch the crocodiles and definitely pictures are allowed this is with the assistance of a tour guide. You can make voluntary donations that goes towards the feeding of the crocodiles, they are fed only fish. I will say it was yet again a beautiful experience.

title: Teveel krokodillen op een veel te kleine ruimte!
text: Katchikally Crocodile Pool was een tegenvaller. Meer dan 100 krokodillen zitten samen in een veel te kleine poel. De dieren op het droge vormen een soort van circusattractie: poseren met de toeristen. Sommige kroko's zaten zelfs in de halfopen en stinkende riolen. Absolutely not done voor zij die van dieren houden.

title: 'Holy Crocs'
text:
We, as a couple, visited the fairly basic crocodile pool while staying at The Kairaba Hotel. One hour should easily do. We had mixed feelings, we had the feeling that the animals were sedated and moreover got a 'Lacoste' touch - say, treating wild and normally voracious animals as pets. 
Optional donations are asked for and I wish to think that at a major part is for croc food. The surroundings give a chance to see how the locals live their lifes. Tip: take a taxi driver 'green' to organise the tour for you.

title: Great opportunity to pet a croc!
text: This croc pool is an excellent place for you to experience what it feels like to pet a crocodile! The place offers a nice visit and the guides there are really good. It is said that more than 100 crocs live in the pool, which is quite amazing since the pool isn't that big (but 5 meters deep and has underground cave system). There is also a local museum inside the park area.

title: Excursie
text:
Geweldig om dit mee te maken, ga zelf on tour met de mannen van TOC
Lokale reis leiders die dit prima doen!
Een gunning factor voor deze mensen

title: quite simply mad
text:
10-15 crocs 3 feet away and NO fences        MAD . 
The walk down to the pool is a must , check out the shops selling hand crafted wooden animals , and cloths

title: Katchikally Crocodile Pool ,a must see in the Gambia
text: Spent a hour or so at the Croc pool today as we looked around the Gambia, well worth a visit to see such prehistoric creatures so close up ,certainly a first for me and the wife stroking a crocodile, interesting little museum attached to the pool so made for a interesting visit ,with a cost of D200 well worth a look.

title: many crocodiles, none doing very much
text: I walked over to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool, in Bakau, which is in the middle of the town and not easy to find. There is first a pleasant museum with some masks and information about Gambia in the war. The pool itself is small and has many crocodiles, none doing very much. I stroked one on the back and it didn't seem to mind.

title: Nära möte med krokodiler
text: Denna park är ganska enkel men det är en häftig upplevelse att vara så nära krokodiler och till och med få klappa dem, om du vågar! Mycket olikt andra parker kan krokodilerna här röra sig mer eller mindre fritt. Jag har varit här två gånger. Ena gången promenerade vi från vårt hotell Sunbeach och även promenaden genom ett enkelt bostadsområde var en uppskattad del av utflykten.

title: Worth a visit!
text: I have been to Katchikally numerous times over the years and it is always worth going back to! What a novel thing to say you’ve done on holiday, to shake a crocodile’s hand! Cheap and an interesting place to visit.

title: Curiosa visita.
text:
Cuando mi guía me comento que visitaríamos un museo con cocodrilos no pensé que esto animales estarían caminando por el recinto y al alcance de la mano (o tu al alcance de ellos ).
El museo refleja la historia, costumbres y tradiciones Gambianas a lo largo de la historia con fotografías y distintos artículos expuestos, destacando los instrumentos musicales entre ellos una kora, grandes tambores ceremoniales y un xilófono de madera de un metro y medio de largo.
Se pueden observar mascaras y vestimentas tradicionales.
Pero lo realmente espectacular es ver a los cocodrilos que se encuentran tanto en el estanque como en sus orillas.
La visita se realiza acompañados por un guía que te indicara que cocodrilo puedes tocar, yo tras tocarlo y ver su inmovilidad en un primer momento pensé que estaba disecado y cuando lo comente el guía hizo que se moviera y fue realmente impresionante ver al cocodrilo con las mandíbulas abiertas tan próximo a mi.
Me explicaron que son cocodrilos del Nilo y que pueden llegar a medir hasta cuatro metros.

title: Eigenlijk heel triest
text:
Het is een attractie die je gezien moet hebben maar eigenlijk is t heel triest. Er liggen heel veel krokodillen in een klein goor watertje en op de paden. 
Het kost ook niet veel, 100 dalasi (€1,70) en na Afloop wordt er om een gift gevraagd om ze te “voeren en te verzorgen”.
Het “mooiste” is eigenlijk het ritje er naar toe. Wij waren op de fiets en dan ga je echt door een soort sloppenwijk met een open riool.  
Goed alternatief is de kleine natuurlijke pool bij cape point, calypso beach bar. Daar liggen ze ook, maar dan op een betere plek.

title: One to make sure you visit!
text:
A really good place to visit in The Gambia. 

A lot of history and cultural significance to the area, a really interesting little museum. 

Highlight obviously the pool and touching the crocodiles! 

As always, expect to be asked for ‘a tip’ on top!

title: worth visiting
text: Very cheap entrance fee, little museum is good and to be literally stepping over crocodiles and being so close to them is great experience !!!

title: fasanating
text: fabulous place with a small museum showing the history of the gambia and the crocodiles are amazing to see and touch.

title: Great place for children of all ages.....
text: Allegedly, this sacred pool was established in 1860's or earlier - it is small and a bit grubby but you can get really close to the crocodiles. The small museum and huge trees - you can stand in one - make the whole visit great fun.

title: Leuke trip
text: Met Falutours deze trip gemaakt. Individuele begeleiding met gids die veel weet. Bij de crocodile pool de krokodillen geaaid. Gids legt alles uit over de krokodillen en ook hoe het is ontstaan

title: Quite a small pool with a large number of crocodiles
text: Called at Katchikally after a visit to Calypso Bar at Cape Point. It is a small pool with a large number of crocodiles in a fairly small area. 200d to enter the site, where there are a number of huts displaying Gambian history before visiting the pool. On reaching the pool a guide approached us and showed us around the pool. The crocodiles are well fed and very docile to the extent that they can be touched

title: Crocos wild!! :)
text: We went here with our local guide sonko (sonko1984@yahoo.com) who arranged everything. This place is cheap to go and close. Atmosphere was good, lots of crocos. And first time i had a chance to touch crocodile!! you can donate some money to this place if you want. i Recommend!

title: Wow!
text:
An amazing experience and a must-do...to touch a crocodile is a truly fantastic thing and they are not 'crunchy'!!!
Look out for the gigantic 'elephant tree'...it's something else

title: Heel leuk
text:
Erg leuk om een keer te doen. Krokodillen aaien doe je niet elke dag :)
Aardige gidsen lopen er rond

title: Not for the scared
text: Having held a baby croc in Zimbabwe, it was good to touch a full size one and have the photo to prove it, which I failed to do in Zim.

title: Nice
text:
We were taken here by our OTG tourist guide. There is a little museum on site followed by Croc pool. Yes, crocs are everywhere and there is also another guide who will speak to you a bit more about this attractions and will take you around the pond and let you touch some of the crocodiles. 

It's pretty cheap to visit, so do make sure you find a time to come here during your holiday.

title: Interesante visita a Kachikali
text: Esta es la tercera vez que estoy en este país, me encanta Gambia, su gente y todo lo que hay que ver en el. La laguna de Kachikali, un lugar sagrado, está muy bien para visitarla, estar al lado de cocodrilos, poder acariciarlos y darles de comer pescado es muy interesante, dar una vuelta y hacer unas cuantas fotos merece la pena, a la entrada hay un mini museo con trajes y fotos que nos introduce un poco a la vida pasada de esta gente, yo particularmente lo recomiendo

title: Kort maar krachtig
text: Wel eens de moeite om te doen, of je nu wil of niet, je zal een krokodil aanraken ,wel eens leuk om aan voelen . Langer dan1 uur ben je er niet binnen.

title: Amazing
text:
It’s only a small place but well worth the visit, the crocodiles were so calm!

The guide was very knowledgeable and you were able to able touch the crocodiles which was pretty amazing.

For the price you pay you wouldn’t get this experience in England!

title: There be crocodiles
text: As with most things in Gambia this attraction is very run down and could do with some cash input, perhaps a bit on the admission fee would help towards that. However the guides were knowledgeable. They even managed to coax the 6 teenagers in our group to touch a crocodile. There is also a small museum on site which gives a bit of an insight into the counties heritage. Overall it is worth a visit

title: Krokodillen gezien
text: Lopend met een lokale gids uit een kiosk tegenover ons hotel (Sun Beach) naar de krokodillenpoel gelopen. Onderweg ernaar toe loop je door een straatarme wijk met open riolering en overal vuilnis. Aangekomen bij het park, ga je eerst naar het museum. Was wel interessant, over de geschiedenis van het park en Gambia als republiek. Er hangen ook veel handgemaakte muziekinstumenten. Lopend in het park kom je bij de krokodillenpoel. Er leven heel veel krokodillen en je kunt er ook een aanraken. De gids heeft veel verteld over het park, het schijnt dat vrouwen die graag een kind willen hebben, zich daar op een speciale plek kunnen wassen met water uit de poel. Er loopt iemand rond of je een bijdrage wil geven voor de vis die ze elke dag moeten kopen. Zolang ze vol zitten, eten ze uiteraard geen toeristen... terug door de wijk hele hordes kinderen achter ons aan die snoep willen en mensen die je schriften willen verkopen voor de kinderen. Het was wel aardig, maar niet spectaculair. Nog een tip: smeren met deet. Door al het water zitten er muggen.

title: fijn om te zien
text: Een krokodil aaien kan je niet elke dag, als je de kans krijgt, moet je het dan ook doen. Een bezoek aan deze poel is bij vele excursies inbegrepen. Ps: doe je excursies met een plaatselijke gids: er zijn er voldoende te vinden op internet die de nodige vergunningen hebben; Zo steun je de plaatselijke bevolking en is je bezoek vele persoonlijker als met een grote Tui of Corendon-bus

title: Krokodillen aanraken
text: Een aanrader als je in Gambia bent. Je krijgt de kans om een krokodil aan te raken. Een ervaring die je niet zo snel zal hebben in Europa

title: Great place to get up close to crocodiles
text: it is amazing to get up close and touch the crocodiles. The entrance fee could be a bit higher so that the guides can get their salary and the crocodiles their fish. You then know what you pay for and there is no need to harass visitors about donations and tips.

title: Krokotiilejä ja historiaa
text: Pääsimme aluksi museoon, jossa oma paikallinen oppaamme kertoi hyvin mielenkiintoisia asioita Gambian historiasta, riiteistä ja heimoista sekä lähihistoriasta. Tämän jälkeen katsomaan krokotiilejä, mitä lapset odottivat. Krokotiilejä oli lampi täynnä ja niitä pääsi silittämään ystävällisen oppaan avustuksella. Varaa tännekin hieman ylimääräistä koska myös täällä kysellään lahjoitusta puistolle.

title: Great place to visit
text:
We were very interested to see and touch the crocodiles at Katchikally crocodile pool and hear about the history and beliefs of the local people. 
Touching a crocodile has to be a bucket list things to do & we were not disappointed. our guide explained how the crocs are cared for and fed and it was a very interesting trip.

title: Crocodile Pool
text: Leuke uitstap. Het museum was minder interessant, maar de Crocodile Pool was zeker de moeite! Heel leuk om ze van zo kortbij te kunnen zien en zelfs aanraken!

title: Die mit dem Krokodil tanzt...
text: Die Krokodile in dem Pool sind schon sehenswert. Sie sind zwar nicht so arg groß, aber möglicherweise liegt das auch an der Fütterung ausschließlich mit Fisch. Am Eingang kommt zunächst ein kleines Museum mit etlichen Exponaten und Photographien. Danach geht man einige Schritte zu dem kleinen See, in dem sich die Krokodile tummeln. Der kleine Rundweg ist romantisch und mit  z.T. uralten Bäumen gesäumt.

title: Make friends with the crocks
text: Waw! It was a very exciting experience visiting this very historic place in my own home town. The crocks are said to be sacred and believed to have healing powers.Good place to mingle and touch the crocks. The staff are very friendly and gives good info about the place.

title: Perfect for cocktails at sunset
text: Enjoy dinner, drinks or a snack next to the crocodile pool watching the birds swooping down to drink

title: Spännande utflykt
text:
Mycket pulshöjande utflykt med lösa krokodiler spatserande !
De är ju dock matade och mätta och inte människoätare.
Men man får ju se vart man sätter fötterna så man inte trampar någon av de 190 stycken krokodilerna på svansen😳

Du får även chansen att klappa en livs levande krokodil !
Sonen på 10 år var den som var tuffast i vårat sällskap 👍🏻

title: Worth a look
text: Museum rooms are interesting, plenty of crocs to See, you can get up close and personal if you wish!!

title: Spannend
text: Graag eens een krokodil geaaid? Zorg wel dat er een gids van het park bij is! Aan de uitgang van het park zit ook een schilder die prachtige Afrikaanse schilderijen maakt.

title: Spännande
text: Man går inne i parken där de har lösa krokodiler, känns ganska säkert, för de matar dem rejält på morgonen 🤔

title: Worth a visit
text: We visited this as a family, the museum is really interesting but small; it gives an insight to the history of the country including war and politics. The croc pool is okay, not sure how much I believe about them not chasing us cos they only eat fish.

title: Weer een leuk uitstapje met Lamin onze taxi chauffeur
text:
We hebben in januari 2018 Bakau Gambia bezocht. Onze taxi chauffeur en gids heeft ons ook naar de Crocodile Pool gebracht. Het was weer een leuk uitstapje met name de rit van het hotel naar de pool was een ware believing.
Als je een goede en betrouwbare  taxi chauffeur zoekt dan is Lamin een goede keus. Met zijn toestemming mocht ik zijn telefoonnummer vermelden. Je kunt hem bereiken met Whats App 002209822596. Hij rijdt rustig en is goed bekend met de omgeving. hij kent veel mensen en vraagt een eerlijke prijs. Een echte aanrader dus.

title: Mooie mythe
text:
Het verhaal achter de krokodillenvijver is een prachtige mythe. Het is o ongelooflijk om zoveel krokodillen.bij elkaar te zien
De belevenis staat of valt wel met de gids die je hebt, denk ik. Wij hadden een hele leuke, Moses, die veel plezier had in zijn werk. Ik vond het ook heel leuk om de krokodil vis te geven. Geen must-see maar toch zeker wel de moeite waard.

title: Up close and personal to crocodiles
text:
Crocodile pool - it's not everyday that you can get to stroke a crocodile but here you can.entrance fee is very cheap and as you walk through the museum you get a sense of history with all the artifacts and pictures on show,you then meander through the gardens hearing and seeing different birds until you come to the croc pool.a guide will go with you explaining about the origins of the pool(used for fertility rites) and take you to stroke crocodiles and will gladly take photos for you.
Excellent way to spend a couple of hours

title: Leuk!
text: Wij zijn er op de fiets naartoe gegaan vanuit Kotu. Mijn kinderen vonden het spannend om een keer te zien. Je loopt zo tussen de krokodillen door en met een goede gids erbij is het museum ook leuk om te zien. Je hoort dan de verhalen erachter.

title: Mixed Feelings!!
text:
My wife and I visited this crocodile pool while staying at the Senegambia Beach Hotel.
I have mixed feelings.
Although it was a great place to visit,
I could not help but feel that some of the animals were sedated.
It just do not seem right a load of people being able to go and touch a crocodile,
but again, having said this it was also a fantastic experience to do such a thing.
They do ask for a donation, although this is optional.
I would like to think that at least half of the donation is put towards the crocs food.
The surrounding area is a bit of an eye-opener, but do give you the chance to see close hand how the not so fortunate locals actually live.
It is worth going for the experience and close up site of these amazing creatures up close, just remain a bit open-minded by the experience.
Tip
If you are staying in or near the Senegambia Beach Hotel, get 'Del-Boy' to organise the tour for you. Well organised and worth the money. He is always down on the beach.

title: Leuk om te doen met lokale taxi
text: Wij zijn hier met Bamba mee naar toe gegaan. Als je met een lokale taxi gaat, lopen zij ook mee en kunnen ze je veel vertellen over het park. Bamba heeft ook Facebook, bamba taxi gambia

title: Great!
text: Definitely worth a visit amazing to sit by the mangrove whilst seeing the sea in the distance. Lovely drinks and food.

title: Mooie ervaring
text: Onze guide Bob heeft ons hier naartoe gebracht. Eerst zijn we door de compounds gelopen om een idee te krijgen van de community en hoe de bevolking hier leeft. Dit is zeker een aanraden om een de visit aan het crocodile pool nog mooier te maken. De krokodillen leven erg vredig, worden dagelijks gevoerd en zijn bijna allemaal tam.

title: Crocodiles up close
text: Katchikally Crocodile is easy to find, once in Bakau you only have to ask and you will be given directions, there is no need to join a your group. Don’t get fooled into signing a donation book near the entrance. Pay the entrance fee at the gate and walk around the pool / lake amongst the crocodiles, the crocs are well fed and take no notice of the tourists walking and standing next to them.

title: Leuk
text: Leuk om in een ochtend te doen .kan je leuk met krokodillen op de foto. Wij zijn er vanuit cape point zelf naartoe gelopen. kan makkelijk kijk wel eerst even op de Google Maps waar je moet zijn.

title: Something to do in Gambia
text:
Difficult to rate:

Before getting to the crocodile pool, there is a museum - 5 little huts: very interesting and informative. 
The crocodile pool is ok, lot of crocodile and there's a keeper that talks about the place. You can get up close to the crocodiles. You are allowed to touch the crocodile. Not sure if that is normal. The keeper said they feed them the night before so they are not hungry when tourist are around. 

The keeper will ask you to donate money to feed the crocodile. I wish I said No because you pay an entrance fee. I gave equivalent of less than $1 so that. 

The most uncomfortable part of this visit was the children at the entrance aggressively begging for money with directions/encouragement from their mothers.

title: Of two minds this is animal exploitation...
text: Conveniently placed for a quick trip from the hotel area and it is not a big attraction. Being an anti-city zoo, anti-circus type family this is NOT wild reptiles in a natural environment what ever the low price. And getting young children to bonk a maybe unhappy creature on the head is not setting a good example for future conduct with Africa wildlife.  Anyway they enjoyed the experience, pool men could be better informed and interactive in the job role.  Information centre was useful.

title: Difficult to rate
text:
Our todler had the best time at the crocodile pool. He really like petting the crocodiles. Kept talking about it all week.
But... this is not natural and in hindsight we should have never participated in this type of animal abuse. 
The adjacent museum is quite informative and we found it a pleasant surprise at this crocodile site.

title: One of the highlights of our trip
text: Crocodiles galore and you're even able to touch one if you dare! Fabulous to see so many together and all for 100 dalasi (less than £2), over a hundred in and around the pool.

title: Well worth a visit...
text: We visited at new year 2018.  Had been here 31 years ago!  It is a small area...the crocks are cute and the little history museum is an interesting and useful addition.  You can (should) walk to it from the Cape Point hotels.

title: Krokodiler överallt
text: Jag tyckte det var rätt obehagligt att besöka Crocodile Pool men det var ingen fara även fast det låg krokodiler precis överallt. Du får klappa dom och riktigt ta del av krokodilernas på nära håll.

title: klein maar leuk
text: Voor 100 dhalasi is het leuke attractie. Tentoonstelling vooraf stelt niet veel voor. Wel heel veel krokodillen in kleine pool.

title: Feeding the crocs
text: This is a place to visit. The crocs are lovely warm creatures and there is always a keeper there. I actually fed them and stroked one. It's a must for animal lovers.

title: krokodil aaien...
text: Eerst kom je door de geschiedenis van Gambia(museum) daarna ga je naar een krokodillen pool. Ik waarschuw je gister goed wat ze zeggen want het blijven dieren die in de natuur leven!! Maar je krijgt de kans om een krokodil aan te raken/aaien. Erg leuk en toch ook een klein beetje spannend!

title: Scary
text:
Having grown up in Malawi and Zimbabwe found it quite scary watching my children touching a crocodile. 

Excellent activity for a family.

title: To touch a crocodile
text: You want to get as close as you have ever been to a crocodile. This is ideal. Not sure about the health and safety side of things but worth a vist. Don't expect too much it is fairly basic.

title: Aggressive guides
text: When we refused to talk to and shake hands with some annoying "guides" there, we were called racists. It is interesting to have a possibility to get in contact with crocodiles, I recommend this place for this opportunity, but beware of the "guides" at the pool

title: Good value experience
text:
Entrance was only 100 dalasi so good value. There's a museum on site, but I personally just wanted to touch a crocodile! Wasn't disappointed, there's looots of them in a small pool, lying around everywhere, calm and lazy just lounging. 
Nice place to spend part of your day - won't take more than an hour of your time!

title: An interesting excursion, but don't expect too much!
text:
Katchikally is one of those 'must see it' excursions that are thrust upon every visitor to the Gambia and, to be fair, it is an interesting way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction - and we didn't find any toilets!
Quite simply, this is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. It is apparently used for fertility rituals and is owned by one of the wealthiest families in Gambia
Yes, you can touch the crocodiles if you feel brave. You will be surrounded by other visitors most of the time and the 'keepers' will try (insistently) to sell you handmade crocodile teeth necklaces and other overpriced craft items.
I was slightly perturbed by the keeper's insistence that we should give him a 'donation' to pay for the crocodile's fish, especially as we had just paid to get in. Was this official or just another Bumster trick? I suspect the latter!
The best bit for me was the small museum at the venue's entrance. There are some interesting examples of local drums and musical instruments with some ceremonial costumes. I was particularly fascinated by the display of old photographs. For me, this was worth the entrance fee on its own.
In short, Katchikally is a tourist trap, but a relatively gentle one. The crocodile custodians are generally pleasant and you will almost certainly enjoy your visit.

title: Nothing spectacular
text: Ok but wouldn't travel a distance to visit. Journey through back streets seeing how locals live was more interesting.

title: Als je toch in de buurt bent ...
text:
Een plas met krokodillen en een museum van locale voudo. That's it.
De meeste toeristen gazn hier naartoe begeleid door een taxichauffeur die ook als gids speelt.

title: Great adventure
text: Amazing time, great guide to help us through the crocodile pools, keep an eye out as there is wildlife everywhere.

title: Pieni alue, jossa nähtävää korkeintaan tunniksi
text: Aluksi oma oppaamme vei meidät kiertämään paikan museon, jossa oli mielenkiintoisia esineitä Gambian historiasta, kulttuurista, musiikista, perinteistä jne. Siellä olisi viettänyt enemmänkin aikaa. Sitten menimme krokotiilialtaalle, jossa kierroksen hoiti paikan oma opas. Krokotiilit oli aamulla syötetty, ja siinä niitä lepäsi toistakymmentä auringossa. Oppaan johdolla niitä sai koskea ja silittää, mikä oli ihan jännittävää. Charlieta, isointa ja vanhinta krokotiilia emme nähneet, oli kuulemma jossain lammikon keskellä veden alla todennäköisesti. Kierroksen lopuksi toki sitten pyydettiin "vapaaehtoista" lahjoitusta paikan toimintaa tukemaan. Monessa kohtaa näki, että turisti oli esim. antanut 100 dalasia, mutta summaa oli jälkikäteen korjailtu ylöspäin. Ovelasti luotiin ryhmäpainetta lahjoittaa isompi summa?

title: Go when it’s quiet
text: We were they only ones there ( apart from the guides) was very quiet and calm...there are literally 100 plus crocodiles, by your feet, no bands round their mouths, no obvious protection.  I thought it would be naff, thoroughly enjoyed it!!

title: Snappy Happy Crocs
text: Quite a small park where you will walk around a pool populated by crocodiles.Dens align the sides of the pool with baby crocs and mothers.They are well fed and looked after.

title: Crocs everywhere!
text: A gentle tour round the small museum, then on to see and touch the crocs. Was it scary - yes! However, we felt very safe with our guide and the Croc Pool staff.

title: Moet je doen als je in de buurt bent!
text:
Vanaf het hotel in Cape Point  zonder gids op eigen gelegenheid er naartoe gewandeld. Google Maps wijst de route perfect. Het is een belevenis op zich. 
Entree is 100 dalasi pp. Via 5 rond davels die dienst doen als museum met veel informatie mbt de geschiedenis van het land. Langs een zandpad kom je voorbij de oude boom waar vroeger besnijdenissen werden uit gevoerd. Net voor de pool wordt je opgevangen door een gids, hij vertelt het over het gebruik en betekenis van de heilige plaats. Hij heeft een paar fotos gemaakt toen wij de krokodillen aaide, leuk om te doen!
Aan het eind hebben wij de gids 100 dalasi gegeven voor de uitleg.

title: A place to visit
text:
A  nice walk through a forest/jungle with lots to see, and then there's t
lots of crocodiles in ponds and walking around. You actually not very far from them

title: Very cool
text: The people running it were easy going and friendly - we enjoyed our visit! I even picked up a crocs tail!

title: Tof om mee te maken
text:
We zijn hier heen gegaan met een lokale gids en lokale taxichauffeur. Er zit een grappig museum bij met allemaal uitleg en attributen van de bewoners van Gambia. Vervolgens loop je via een bos met een zeer oude boom naar een vijver waar allemaal krokodillen liggen. Je kan ze aanraken, voeden met vis en foto's en video maken.  

Heb niet het idee dat de dieren mishandeld worden.

title: Dundee
text:
Went through the museum at the beginning where your shown a bit of the history of the Gambian people going all the way back to their magical beliefs up to when the queen visited and also the recruiting of troops from Gambia in the Second World War 

The crocodile pool is pretty good they’ll be couple out the water where they’ll be a chance to have your photo taken with the crocs. They’ll also explain about the spiritual beliefs of the pool. 

On the whole not a bad bit of money spent buy don’t get prepared to be blown away

title: A crocodile petting zoo with local heritage museum
text:
We’ve been here early October before high Season (Oct 15th-Dec)

It’s a small place best visited out of season. The guides have time to show you around and tell something about the crocs.

If you take of one of the locals to take you there you can stay away from the tourist traffic days. I wouldn’t wanna be there when there’s a group of 20-30 tourist that just got there.

That said, it’s good fun and a good thrill. Even though they’re well fed with fish, it’s still an exciting event to be able to touch them and feel the skin of these prehistoric survivors.

Entrance fee is about 100 dalasi.

This includes the museum with some of the festive and traditional clothing, music instruments and the juju (voodoo) department.

title: Snappy!
text: We had a great time here. The museum first of all was insightful, learning about local tribes and their tools of trade. Then through to see the crocs. There were a lot of crocs so everyone could take turns in stroking them. The keepers would tell you which ones to stay away from and which ones to touch. They were on the ball and made sure everyone was safe. Even my children got to touch them. Great place to visit.

title: Crocodile pool in a very poor neighborhood.
text: We visited the crocodile with a local guide. He did not know the location exactly so we stranded a few hundred meters from the entrance. The road are terrible and if you have to walk you realize you walking along open sewer. First thing to visit is the museum that gives a good impression of the area in the old days. When you walk along you will find the crocodiles that have been fed already so you are able to touch them. Around the pool it is relative clean but the garbage has been thrown into the behind the trees it looks like a garbage disposal area. Still touching the crocodiles is a special experience.

title: Excursies Met lokale gids Yaya Mannah
text: Ervaring zoveel krokodillen en het lijkt ongevaarlijk om ze aan te raken. Ik heb het voorzichtig toch gedaan.

title: Been able to touch the crocs🙄🙄🙄
text: Went to see crocs, touched a live croc and it didnt bite me. Believe me cro s were evefywhere liten to the guides an obey what they tell you.

title: A unique experience - MUST visit place
text:
This was my second time to Gambia and I could not miss to visit this place one more time.  Last time it was summer so the pool was not full of water but this time it was raining and the experience was simply amazing.  The pool was full of water so could not see the Crocs lying on the side.
You enter the park by paying a nominal fee and if lucky find crocodiles walking along with you on the side or may be just lying next to the walking path.  They are harmless until she is a female.  Female is more into defense to protect her eggs.  You reach near the pool and find so many of them just lying over there, may be waiting for you to sit besides them and have your pictures taken.  Believe me, it is an amazing experience irrespective you like animals or not.  These Crocs are never fed meat and they eat almost 3,000 Kg of fish daily (that's what rangers told, not sure how much true it is).  Please make sure that the rangers are around and guide you which Croc to be with while taking the pictures.  Stay away from the female Crocs.  If the water level is a bit low in the pool then you can go close by and see many Crocs walking towards you from the water or the side.  There is nothing to worry about but you must need to take precautions while with animals.  There is a small shop that sells crocodile tooth and they are not expensive, may be around 150 - 200 dalasis.  They also ask for the donation and have maintained a register of donors.
They have a nicely maintained museum in the front that depicts many ancient and authentic articles including weapons, cooking vessels, musical instruments etc.  There is also a history of Gambia associated with it if you are interested into it.
It is a belief of the locals that a lady who is not able to conceive a baby can visit this place and take a dip in the pool to be an expectant mom in the future.

title: Impactante
text: Interesante ver y tocar a estos animales en una visita también cultural, donde puedes visitar su museo y ver parte de la historia de este país.

title: Nice and creepy
text:
A trip to Bakau is more than visiting a crocodile pool. You also see how poor this neighbourhood is. Pretty shocking. Children are happy if you give them something to eat or something small like a ball. 
Bakau pool is completely filled with crocs. You have to see it to believe it. You can touch them ( I' m not a fan). I' ve filmed it for my pupils, they found me an awesome teacher :-)
